pli-tv-kd1:1.0.1.eng: 1. The account with the Bodhi tree

pli-tv-kd1:1.0.2.eng: Homage to the Buddha, the Perfected One, the fully Awakened One

pli-tv-kd1:1.1.1.pli: Tena samayena buddho bhagavā uruvelāyaṃ viharati najjā nerañjarāya tīre bodhirukkhamūle paṭhamābhisambuddho.
pli-tv-kd1:1.1.1.eng: Soon after his awakening, the Buddha was staying at Uruvelā on the bank of the river Nerañjara at the foot of a Bodhi tree.

pli-tv-kd1:1.1.2.pli: Atha kho bhagavā bodhirukkhamūle sattāhaṃ ekapallaṅkena nisīdi vimuttisukhapaṭisaṃvedī.
pli-tv-kd1:1.1.2.eng: There the Buddha sat cross-legged for seven days without moving, experiencing the bliss of freedom.

pli-tv-kd1:1.2.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā rattiyā paṭhamaṃ yāmaṃ paṭiccasamuppādaṃ anulomapaṭilomaṃ manasākāsi—
pli-tv-kd1:1.2.1.eng: Then, in the first part of the night, the Buddha reflected on dependent origination in forward and reverse order:

pli-tv-kd1:1.2.2.pli: “Avijjāpaccayā saṅkhārā, saṅkhārapaccayā viññāṇaṃ, viññāṇapaccayā nāmarūpaṃ, nāmarūpapaccayā saḷāyatanaṃ, saḷāyatanapaccayā phasso, phassapaccayā vedanā, vedanāpaccayā taṇhā, taṇhāpaccayā upādānaṃ, upādānapaccayā bhavo, bhavapaccayā jāti, jātipaccayā jarāmaraṇaṃ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā sambhavanti.
pli-tv-kd1:1.2.2.eng: “Ignorance is the condition for intentional activities; intentional activities are the condition for consciousness; consciousness is the condition for name and form; name and form are the condition for the six sense spheres; the six sense spheres are the condition for contact; contact is the condition for feeling; feeling is the condition for craving; craving is the condition for grasping; grasping is the condition for existence; existence is the condition for birth; birth is the condition for old age and death, for grief, sorrow, pain, aversion, and distress to come to be.

pli-tv-kd1:1.2.3.eng: This is how there is the origin of this whole mass of suffering.

pli-tv-kd1:1.2.4.pli: Avijjāya tveva asesavirāganirodhā saṅkhāranirodho, saṅkhāranirodhā viññāṇanirodho, viññāṇanirodhā nāmarūpanirodho, nāmarūpanirodhā saḷāyatananirodho, saḷāyatananirodhā phassanirodho, phassanirodhā vedanānirodho, vedanānirodhā taṇhānirodho, taṇhānirodhā upādānanirodho, upādānanirodhā bhavanirodho, bhavanirodhā jātinirodho, jātinirodhā jarāmaraṇaṃ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā nirujjhanti.
pli-tv-kd1:1.2.4.eng: But with the complete fading away and end of ignorance comes the end of intentional activities; with the end of intentional activities comes the end of consciousness; with the end of consciousness comes the end of name and form; with the end of name and form comes the end of the six sense spheres; with the end of the six sense spheres comes the end of contact; with the end of contact comes the end of feeling; with the end of feeling comes the end of craving; with the end of craving comes the end of grasping; with the end of grasping comes the end of existence; with the end of existence comes the end of birth; with the end of birth comes the end of old age and death, and the end of sorrow, lamentation, pain, aversion, and distress.

pli-tv-kd1:1.2.5.eng: This is how there is the end of this whole mass of suffering.”

pli-tv-kd1:1.3.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etamatthaṃ viditvā tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi—
pli-tv-kd1:1.3.1.eng: Seeing the significance of this, the Buddha uttered a heartfelt exclamation:

pli-tv-kd1:1.3.3.eng: To the energetic brahmin who practices absorption,

pli-tv-kd1:1.3.4.eng: Then all his doubts are dispelled,

pli-tv-kd1:1.3.5.eng: Since he understands the natural order and its conditions.”

pli-tv-kd1:1.4.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā rattiyā majjhimaṃ yāmaṃ paṭiccasamuppādaṃ anulomapaṭilomaṃ manasākāsi—
pli-tv-kd1:1.4.1.eng: In the middle part of the night, the Buddha again reflected on dependent origination in forward and reverse order:

pli-tv-kd1:1.4.2.eng: “Ignorance is the condition for intentional activities; intentional activities are the condition for consciousness; consciousness is the condition for name and form …

pli-tv-kd1:1.4.3.eng: This is how there is the origin of this whole mass of suffering. …

pli-tv-kd1:1.4.4.eng: This is how there is the end of this whole mass of suffering.”

pli-tv-kd1:1.5.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etamatthaṃ viditvā tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi—
pli-tv-kd1:1.5.1.eng: Seeing the significance of this, the Buddha uttered a heartfelt exclamation:

pli-tv-kd1:1.5.3.eng: To the energetic brahmin who practices absorption,

pli-tv-kd1:1.5.4.eng: Then all his doubts are dispelled,

pli-tv-kd1:1.5.5.eng: Since he’s understood the end of the conditions.”

pli-tv-kd1:1.6.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā rattiyā pacchimaṃ yāmaṃ paṭiccasamuppādaṃ anulomapaṭilomaṃ manasākāsi—
pli-tv-kd1:1.6.1.eng: In the last part of the night, the Buddha again reflected on dependent origination in forward and reverse order:

pli-tv-kd1:1.6.2.eng: “Ignorance is the condition for intentional activities; intentional activities are the condition for consciousness; consciousness is the condition for name and form …

pli-tv-kd1:1.6.3.eng: This is how there is the origin of this whole mass of suffering. …

pli-tv-kd1:1.6.4.eng: This is how there is the end of this whole mass of suffering.”

pli-tv-kd1:1.7.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etamatthaṃ viditvā tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi—
pli-tv-kd1:1.7.1.eng: Seeing the significance of this, the Buddha uttered a heartfelt exclamation:

pli-tv-kd1:1.7.3.eng: To the energetic brahmin who practices absorption,

pli-tv-kd1:1.7.4.eng: He defeats the army of the Lord of Death,

pli-tv-kd1:1.7.5.eng: Like the sun beaming in the sky.”

pli-tv-kd1:1.7.6.eng: The account with the Bodhi tree is finished.

pli-tv-kd1:2.1.0.eng: 2. The account with the goatherd’s banyan tree

pli-tv-kd1:2.1.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā sattāhassa accayena tamhā samādhimhā vuṭṭhahitvā bodhirukkhamūlā yena ajapālanigrodho tenupasaṅkami, upasaṅkamitvā ajapālanigrodhamūle sattāhaṃ ekapallaṅkena nisīdi vimuttisukhapaṭisaṃvedī.
pli-tv-kd1:2.1.1.eng: After seven days, the Buddha came out from that stillness and went from the Bodhi tree to a goatherd’s banyan tree. There too he sat cross-legged for seven days without moving, experiencing the bliss of freedom.

pli-tv-kd1:2.2.1.pli: Atha kho aññataro huṃhuṅkajātiko brāhmaṇo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami.
pli-tv-kd1:2.2.1.eng: Then a brahmin devoted to mystical mantras went up to the Buddha,
pli-tv-kd1:2.2.1.comm: According to Bhikkhu Sujato’s notes to the parallel verse at Ud 1.4, huṁhuṅkajātika brāhmaṇa refers to a brahmin who utters the syllable huṁ. In the Chāndogya Upaniṣad, this syllable, like the syllable om, had a ritualistic purpose with mystical connotations. In the verse below, “the brahmin … who does not murmur mystical mantras”, brāhmaṇa … nihuṁhuṅka, is intended to capture the idea that a true brahmin, a perfected individual, does not utter such syllables. See https://discourse.suttacentral.net/t/on-the-brahmin-who-said-hu.

pli-tv-kd1:2.2.3.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi.

pli-tv-kd1:2.2.4.pli: Ekamantaṃ ṭhito kho so brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca—

pli-tv-kd1:2.2.5.pli: “kittāvatā nu kho, bho gotama, brāhmaṇo hoti, katame ca pana brāhmaṇakaraṇā dhammā”ti?
pli-tv-kd1:2.2.5.eng: “Good Gotama, how is one a brahmin? What are the qualities that make one a brahmin?”

pli-tv-kd1:2.3.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etamatthaṃ viditvā tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi—
pli-tv-kd1:2.3.1.eng: Seeing the significance of this, the Buddha uttered a heartfelt exclamation:

pli-tv-kd1:2.3.2.eng: “The brahmin who has shut out bad qualities,

pli-tv-kd1:2.3.3.eng: Who does not murmur mystical mantras, but is free from flaws and self-controlled,

pli-tv-kd1:2.3.4.eng: Who has reached final knowledge and has fulfilled the spiritual life—

pli-tv-kd1:2.3.5.eng: He may rightly proclaim the highest doctrine,
pli-tv-kd1:2.3.5.comm: Bhikkhu Sujato notes that the phrase brahmavāda only occurs at Ud 1.4 and here in the entire Pali Canon. It does occur, however, in pre-Buddhist Vedic texts in the meaning “orthodox Vedic doctrine” (Atharva Veda 11.3.26a, 15.1.8a; Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 14.7.3.1; Chāndogya Upaniṣad 2.24.1). To accord with the Buddhist teachings, the Buddha normally reinterprets the word brahma as “the highest”, and I expect this is the case also here.

pli-tv-kd1:2.3.6.eng: Having no pride about anything in the world.”

pli-tv-kd1:2.3.7.eng: The account with the goatherd’s banyan tree is finished.

pli-tv-kd1:3.1.0.eng: 3. The account with the powderpuff tree

pli-tv-kd1:3.1.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā sattāhassa accayena tamhā samādhimhā vuṭṭhahitvā ajapālanigrodhamūlā yena mucalindo tenupasaṅkami, upasaṅkamitvā mucalindamūle sattāhaṃ ekapallaṅkena nisīdi vimuttisukhapaṭisaṃvedī.
pli-tv-kd1:3.1.1.eng: After seven days, the Buddha came out from that stillness and went from the goatherd’s banyan tree to a powderpuff tree. There too he sat cross-legged for seven days without moving, experiencing the bliss of freedom.
pli-tv-kd1:3.1.1.comm: According to SAF, pp. 85-86, mucalinda is a Barringtonia racemosa, sometimes known as a “powder-puff tree”.

pli-tv-kd1:3.2.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena mahā akālamegho udapādi, sattāhavaddalikā sītavātaduddinī.
pli-tv-kd1:3.2.1.eng: Just then an unseasonal storm was approaching, bringing seven days of rain, cold winds, and clouds.

pli-tv-kd1:3.2.2.pli: Atha kho mucalindo nāgarājā sakabhavanā nikkhamitvā bhagavato kāyaṃ sattakkhattuṃ bhogehi parikkhipitvā uparimuddhani mahantaṃ phaṇaṃ karitvā aṭṭhāsi—
pli-tv-kd1:3.2.2.eng: Mucalinda, the dragon king, came out from his abode. He encircled the body of the Buddha with seven coils and spread his large hood over his head, thinking,

pli-tv-kd1:3.2.3.pli: “mā bhagavantaṃ sītaṃ, mā bhagavantaṃ uṇhaṃ, mā bhagavantaṃ ḍaṃsamakasavātātapasarīsapasamphasso”ti.
pli-tv-kd1:3.2.3.eng: “May the Buddha not be hot or cold, nor be bothered by horseflies or mosquitoes, by the wind or the burning sun, or by creeping animals or insects.”

pli-tv-kd1:3.3.1.pli: Atha kho mucalindo nāgarājā sattāhassa accayena viddhaṃ vigatavalāhakaṃ devaṃ viditvā bhagavato kāyā bhoge viniveṭhetvā sakavaṇṇaṃ paṭisaṃharitvā māṇavakavaṇṇaṃ abhinimminitvā bhagavato purato aṭṭhāsi pañjaliko bhagavantaṃ namassamāno.
pli-tv-kd1:3.3.1.eng: After seven days, when he knew the sky was clear, Mucalinda unraveled his coils from the Buddha’s body and transformed himself into a young brahmin. He then stood in front of the Buddha, raising his joined palms in veneration.

pli-tv-kd1:3.3.2.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etamatthaṃ viditvā tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi—
pli-tv-kd1:3.3.2.eng: Seeing the significance of this, the Buddha uttered a heartfelt exclamation:

pli-tv-kd1:3.4.2.eng: Who sees the Teaching that they have learned.

pli-tv-kd1:3.4.3.eng: Kindness to the world is happiness,

pli-tv-kd1:3.4.4.eng: For one who’s harmless to living beings.

pli-tv-kd1:3.4.5.eng: Dispassion for the world is happiness,

pli-tv-kd1:3.4.6.eng: For one who overcomes worldly pleasures.

pli-tv-kd1:3.4.8.eng: This, indeed, is the highest bliss.”

pli-tv-kd1:3.4.9.eng: The account with the powderpuff tree is finished.

pli-tv-kd1:4.1.0.eng: 4. The account with the ape-flower tree

pli-tv-kd1:4.1.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā sattāhassa accayena tamhā samādhimhā vuṭṭhahitvā mucalindamūlā yena rājāyatanaṃ tenupasaṅkami, upasaṅkamitvā rājāyatanamūle sattāhaṃ ekapallaṅkena nisīdi vimuttisukhapaṭisaṃvedī.
pli-tv-kd1:4.1.1.eng: After seven days, the Buddha came out from that stillness and went from the powderpuff tree to an ape-flower tree. There too he sat cross-legged for seven days without moving, experiencing the bliss of freedom.
pli-tv-kd1:4.1.1.comm: According to SAF, p. 72, rājāyatana is a Buchanania axillaris, sometimes known as an “ape-flower tree”.

pli-tv-kd1:4.2.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena tapussa bhallikā vāṇijā ukkalā taṃ desaṃ addhānamaggappaṭipannā honti.
pli-tv-kd1:4.2.1.eng: Just then the merchants Tapussa and Bhallika were traveling from Ukkalā to that area.

pli-tv-kd1:4.2.2.pli: Atha kho tapussabhallikānaṃ vāṇijānaṃ ñātisālohitā devatā tapussabhallike vāṇije etadavoca—
pli-tv-kd1:4.2.2.eng: Then a god who was a former relative of theirs said to them,

pli-tv-kd1:4.2.3.eng: “Sirs, a Buddha who has just attained awakening is staying at the foot of an ape-flower tree.

pli-tv-kd1:4.2.4.pli: gacchatha taṃ bhagavantaṃ manthena ca madhupiṇḍikāya ca patimānetha;
pli-tv-kd1:4.2.4.eng: Go to that Buddha and offer him crackers and honey.
pli-tv-kd1:4.2.4.comm: “Crackers” renders mantha. See discussion in Appendix of Technical Terms.

pli-tv-kd1:4.2.5.pli: taṃ vo bhavissati dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāyā”ti.
pli-tv-kd1:4.2.5.eng: That will be for your benefit and happiness for a long time.”

pli-tv-kd1:4.3.1.pli: Atha kho tapussabhallikā vāṇijā manthañca madhupiṇḍikañca ādāya yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu, upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhaṃsu.
pli-tv-kd1:4.3.1.eng: And they took crackers and honey and went to the Buddha. They bowed down

pli-tv-kd1:4.3.2.pli: Ekamantaṃ ṭhitā kho tapussabhallikā vāṇijā bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ—

pli-tv-kd1:4.3.3.pli: “paṭiggaṇhātu no, bhante, bhagavā manthañca madhupiṇḍikañca, yaṃ amhākaṃ assa dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāyā”ti.
pli-tv-kd1:4.3.3.eng: “Sir, please accept the crackers and honey from us. That will be for our benefit and happiness for a long time.”

pli-tv-kd1:4.4.3.pli: Kimhi nu kho ahaṃ paṭiggaṇheyyaṃ manthañca madhupiṇḍikañcā”ti?
pli-tv-kd1:4.4.3.eng: In what should I receive the crackers and honey?”

pli-tv-kd1:4.4.4.pli: Atha kho cattāro mahārājāno bhagavato cetasā cetoparivitakkamaññāya catuddisā cattāro selamaye patte bhagavato upanāmesuṃ—
pli-tv-kd1:4.4.4.eng: Then, reading the mind of the Buddha, the four great kings offered him four crystal bowls from the four directions, saying,

pli-tv-kd1:4.4.5.eng: “Here, sir, please receive the crackers and honey in these.”

pli-tv-kd1:4.4.6.pli: Paṭiggahesi bhagavā paccagghe selamaye patte manthañca madhupiṇḍikañca, paṭiggahetvā paribhuñji.
pli-tv-kd1:4.4.6.eng: After receiving the crackers and honey in one of the valuable crystal bowls, the Buddha ate them.

pli-tv-kd1:4.5.1.pli: Atha kho tapussabhallikā vāṇijā bhagavantaṃ onītapattapāṇiṃ viditvā bhagavato pādesu sirasā nipatitvā bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ—
pli-tv-kd1:4.5.1.eng: When Tapussa and Bhallika knew that the Buddha had finished his meal, they bowed down with their heads at his feet, and said,

pli-tv-kd1:4.5.2.pli: “ete mayaṃ, bhante, bhagavantaṃ saraṇaṃ gacchāma dhammañca, upāsake no bhagavā dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupete saraṇaṃ gate”ti.
pli-tv-kd1:4.5.2.eng: “Sir, we go for refuge to the Buddha and the Teaching. Please accept us as lay followers who have gone for refuge for life.”

pli-tv-kd1:4.5.3.pli: Te ca loke paṭhamaṃ upāsakā ahesuṃ dvevācikā.
pli-tv-kd1:4.5.3.eng: By means of the double refuge, they became the first lay followers in the world.

pli-tv-kd1:4.5.4.eng: The account with the ape-flower tree is finished.

pli-tv-kd1:5.1.0.eng: 5. The account of the supreme being’s request

pli-tv-kd1:5.1.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā sattāhassa accayena tamhā samādhimhā vuṭṭhahitvā rājāyatanamūlā yena ajapālanigrodho tenupasaṅkami.
pli-tv-kd1:5.1.1.eng: After seven days, the Buddha came out from that stillness and went from the ape-flower tree to a goatherd’s banyan tree,

pli-tv-kd1:5.2.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavato rahogatassa paṭisallīnassa evaṃ cetaso parivitakko udapādi—
pli-tv-kd1:5.2.1.eng: Then, while reflecting in private, the Buddha thought this:

pli-tv-kd1:5.2.2.pli: “adhigato kho myāyaṃ dhammo gambhīro duddaso duranubodho santo paṇīto atakkāvacaro nipuṇo paṇḍitavedanīyo.
pli-tv-kd1:5.2.2.eng: “I have discovered this profound truth, so hard to see, so hard to comprehend. It’s peaceful and sublime, subtle, beyond the intellect, and knowable only to the wise.

pli-tv-kd1:5.2.3.pli: Ālayarāmā kho panāyaṃ pajā ālayaratā ālayasammuditā.
pli-tv-kd1:5.2.3.eng: But human beings delight in holding on, find pleasure in holding on, rejoice in holding on,

pli-tv-kd1:5.2.4.pli: Ālayarāmāya kho pana pajāya ālayaratāya ālayasammuditāya duddasaṃ idaṃ ṭhānaṃ yadidaṃ idappaccayatāpaṭiccasamuppādo;
pli-tv-kd1:5.2.4.eng: and because of that it’s hard for them to see causal relationships, dependent origination.

pli-tv-kd1:5.2.5.pli: idampi kho ṭhānaṃ sududdasaṃ yadidaṃ sabbasaṅkhārasamatho sabbūpadhipaṭinissaggo taṇhākkhayo virāgo nirodho nibbānaṃ.
pli-tv-kd1:5.2.5.eng: This too is very hard for them to see: the stilling of all intentional activities, the giving up of all ownership, the stopping of craving, fading away, ending, extinguishment.

pli-tv-kd1:5.2.6.pli: Ahañceva kho pana dhammaṃ deseyyaṃ, pare ca me na ājāneyyuṃ, so mamassa kilamatho, sā mamassa vihesā”ti.
pli-tv-kd1:5.2.6.eng: If I were to teach this truth, others would not understand, and that would be wearying and troublesome for me.”

pli-tv-kd1:5.3.1.pli: Apissu bhagavantaṃ imā anacchariyā gāthāyo paṭibhaṃsu pubbe assutapubbā—
pli-tv-kd1:5.3.1.eng: And spontaneously, these verses never heard before occurred to the Buddha:

pli-tv-kd1:5.3.3.eng: There’s no point in making it known.

pli-tv-kd1:5.3.4.eng: For those overcome by sensual desire and ill will,

pli-tv-kd1:5.3.5.eng: This truth is hard to understand.

pli-tv-kd1:5.3.6.eng: Those who are excited by sensual desire,

pli-tv-kd1:5.3.7.eng: Obstructed by a mass of darkness,

pli-tv-kd1:5.3.8.eng: Won’t see what goes against the stream,

pli-tv-kd1:5.3.9.eng: What’s subtle and refined, profound and hard to see.”

pli-tv-kd1:5.4.1.pli: Itiha bhagavato paṭisañcikkhato appossukkatāya cittaṃ namati, no dhammadesanāya.
pli-tv-kd1:5.4.1.eng: When the Buddha reflected like this, he inclined to inactivity, not to teaching.

pli-tv-kd1:5.4.2.pli: Atha kho brahmuno sahampatissa bhagavato cetasā cetoparivitakkamaññāya etadahosi—
pli-tv-kd1:5.4.2.eng: Just then the supreme being Sahampati read the mind of the Buddha. He thought,

pli-tv-kd1:5.4.3.pli: “nassati vata bho loko, vinassati vata bho loko, yatra hi nāma tathāgatassa arahato sammāsambuddhassa appossukkatāya cittaṃ namati, no dhammadesanāyā”ti.
pli-tv-kd1:5.4.3.eng: “The world is lost; it’s perished!—for the Buddha, perfected and fully awakened, inclines to inaction, not to teaching.”

pli-tv-kd1:5.5.1.pli: Atha kho brahmā sahampati—seyyathāpi nāma balavā puriso samiñjitaṃ vā bāhaṃ pasāreyya, pasāritaṃ vā bāhaṃ samiñjeyya; evameva—brahmaloke antarahito bhagavato purato pāturahosi.
pli-tv-kd1:5.5.1.eng: Then, just as a strong man might bend or stretch his arm, Sahampati disappeared from the world of supreme beings and appeared in front of the Buddha.

pli-tv-kd1:5.6.1.pli: Atha kho brahmā sahampati ekaṃsaṃ uttarāsaṅgaṃ karitvā dakkhiṇajāṇumaṇḍalaṃ pathaviyaṃ nihantvā yena bhagavā tenañjaliṃ paṇāmetvā bhagavantaṃ etadavoca—
pli-tv-kd1:5.6.1.eng: He arranged his upper robe over one shoulder, placed his right knee on the ground, raised his joined palms, and said,

pli-tv-kd1:5.6.2.pli: “desetu, bhante, bhagavā dhammaṃ, desetu sugato dhammaṃ.

pli-tv-kd1:5.6.3.pli: Santi sattā apparajakkhajātikā, assavanatā dhammassa parihāyanti, bhavissanti dhammassa aññātāro”ti.
pli-tv-kd1:5.6.3.eng: There are beings with little dust in their eyes who are ruined because of not hearing the Teaching. There will be those who understand.”

pli-tv-kd1:5.7.1.pli: Idamavoca brahmā sahampati, idaṃ vatvāna athāparaṃ etadavoca—
pli-tv-kd1:5.7.1.eng: This is what Sahampati said, and he added:

pli-tv-kd1:5.7.3.eng: An impure teaching appeared, conceived by defiled people.

pli-tv-kd1:5.7.4.eng: Open this door to the freedom from death!

pli-tv-kd1:5.7.5.eng: Let them hear the Teaching, discovered by the Pure One.

pli-tv-kd1:5.7.6.eng: Just as one standing on a rocky mountain top

pli-tv-kd1:5.7.7.eng: Would see the people all around,

pli-tv-kd1:5.7.9.eng: Ascend the temple of the Truth.

pli-tv-kd1:5.7.10.eng: Being rid of sorrow, look upon the people,

pli-tv-kd1:5.7.11.eng: Sunk in grief, overcome by birth and old age.

pli-tv-kd1:5.7.13.eng: Leader of travelers, wander the world without obligation.

pli-tv-kd1:5.7.15.eng: There will be those who understand.”

pli-tv-kd1:5.8.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, bhagavā brahmānaṃ sahampatiṃ etadavoca—
pli-tv-kd1:5.8.1.eng: Twice the Buddha repeated to Sahampati what he had thought, and on both occasions Sahampati repeated his request.

pli-tv-kd1:5.8.3.pli: ‘adhigato kho myāyaṃ dhammo gambhīro duddaso duranubodho santo paṇīto atakkāvacaro nipuṇo paṇḍitavedanīyo.

pli-tv-kd1:5.8.4.pli: Ālayarāmā kho panāyaṃ pajā ālayaratā ālayasammuditā.

pli-tv-kd1:5.8.5.pli: Ālayarāmāya kho pana pajāya ālayaratāya ālayasammuditāya duddasaṃ idaṃ ṭhānaṃ yadidaṃ idappaccayatāpaṭiccasamuppādo;

pli-tv-kd1:5.8.6.pli: idampi kho ṭhānaṃ sududdasaṃ yadidaṃ sabbasaṅkhārasamatho sabbūpadhipaṭinissaggo taṇhākkhayo virāgo nirodho nibbānaṃ.

pli-tv-kd1:5.8.7.pli: Ahañceva kho pana dhammaṃ deseyyaṃ, pare ca me na ājāneyyuṃ, so mamassa kilamatho, sā mamassa vihesā’ti.

pli-tv-kd1:5.8.8.pli: Apissu maṃ, brahme, imā anacchariyā gāthāyo paṭibhaṃsu pubbe assutapubbā—

pli-tv-kd1:5.8.17.pli: Itiha me, brahme, paṭisañcikkhato appossukkatāya cittaṃ namati no dhammadesanāyā”ti.

pli-tv-kd1:5.9.1.pli: Dutiyampi kho brahmā sahampati bhagavantaṃ etadavoca—

pli-tv-kd1:5.9.2.pli: “desetu, bhante, bhagavā dhammaṃ, desetu sugato dhammaṃ;

pli-tv-kd1:5.9.3.pli: santi sattā apparajakkhajātikā, assavanatā dhammassa parihāyanti, bhavissanti dhammassa aññātāro”ti.

pli-tv-kd1:5.9.4.pli: Idamavoca brahmā sahampati, idaṃ vatvāna athāparaṃ etadavoca—

pli-tv-kd1:5.9.19.pli: Dutiyampi kho bhagavā brahmānaṃ sahampatiṃ etadavoca—

pli-tv-kd1:5.9.21.pli: ‘adhigato kho myāyaṃ dhammo gambhīro duddaso duranubodho santo paṇīto atakkāvacaro nipuṇo paṇḍitavedanīyo.

pli-tv-kd1:5.9.22.pli: Ālayarāmā kho panāyaṃ pajā ālayaratā ālayasammuditā.

pli-tv-kd1:5.9.23.pli: Ālayarāmāya kho pana pajāya ālayaratāya ālayasammuditāya duddasaṃ idaṃ ṭhānaṃ yadidaṃ idappaccayatāpaṭiccasamuppādo;

pli-tv-kd1:5.9.24.pli: idampi kho ṭhānaṃ sududdasaṃ yadidaṃ sabbasaṅkhārasamatho sabbūpadhipaṭinissaggo taṇhākkhayo virāgo nirodho nibbānaṃ.

pli-tv-kd1:5.9.25.pli: Ahañceva kho pana dhammaṃ deseyyaṃ, pare ca me na ājāneyyuṃ, so mamassa kilamatho, sā mamassa vihesā’ti.

pli-tv-kd1:5.9.26.pli: Apissu maṃ, brahme, imā anacchariyā gāthāyo paṭibhaṃsu pubbe assutapubbā—

pli-tv-kd1:5.9.35.pli: Itiha me, brahme, paṭisañcikkhato appossukkatāya cittaṃ namati, no dhammadesanāyā”ti.

pli-tv-kd1:5.9.36.pli: Tatiyampi kho brahmā sahampati bhagavantaṃ etadavoca—

pli-tv-kd1:5.9.37.pli: “desetu, bhante, bhagavā dhammaṃ, desetu sugato dhammaṃ.

pli-tv-kd1:5.9.38.pli: Santi sattā apparajakkhajātikā, assavanatā dhammassa parihāyanti, bhavissanti dhammassa aññātāro”ti.

pli-tv-kd1:5.9.39.pli: Idamavoca brahmā sahampati, idaṃ vatvāna athāparaṃ etadavoca—

pli-tv-kd1:5.10.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā brahmuno ca ajjhesanaṃ viditvā sattesu ca kāruññataṃ paṭicca buddhacakkhunā lokaṃ volokesi.
pli-tv-kd1:5.10.1.eng: The Buddha understood the request of that supreme being. Then, with the eye of a Buddha, he surveyed the world out of compassion for sentient beings.

pli-tv-kd1:5.11.1.pli: Addasā kho bhagavā buddhacakkhunā lokaṃ volokento satte apparajakkhe mahārajakkhe tikkhindriye mudindriye svākāre dvākāre suviññāpaye duviññāpaye, appekacce paralokavajjabhayadassāvine viharante, appekacce na paralokavajjabhayadassāvine viharante.
pli-tv-kd1:5.11.1.eng: He saw beings with little dust in their eyes and with much dust in their eyes, with sharp faculties and with dull faculties, with good qualities and with bad qualities, easy to teach and difficult to teach. He even saw some who regarded the next world as dangerous and to be avoided, while others did not.
pli-tv-kd1:5.11.1.comm: I follow the reading in the PTS edition of the Pali, which omits the phrase appekacce na paralokavajjabhayadassāvine viharante.

pli-tv-kd1:5.11.2.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma uppaliniyaṃ vā paduminiyaṃ vā puṇḍarīkiniyaṃ vā appekaccāni uppalāni vā padumāni vā puṇḍarīkāni vā udake jātāni udake saṃvaḍḍhāni udakānuggatāni anto nimuggaposīni, appekaccāni uppalāni vā padumāni vā puṇḍarīkāni vā udake jātāni udake saṃvaḍḍhāni samodakaṃ ṭhitāni, appekaccāni uppalāni vā padumāni vā puṇḍarīkāni vā udake jātāni udake saṃvaḍḍhāni udakaṃ accuggamma ṭhitāni anupalittāni udakena;
pli-tv-kd1:5.11.2.eng: It was just like blue, red, and white lotuses, sprouted and grown in a lotus pond: some remain submerged in the water without rising out of it, others reach the surface of the water, while others still rise out of the water without being touched by it.

pli-tv-kd1:5.11.3.pli: evamevaṃ bhagavā buddhacakkhunā lokaṃ volokento addasa satte apparajakkhe mahārajakkhe tikkhindriye mudindriye svākāre dvākāre suviññāpaye duviññāpaye, appekacce paralokavajjabhayadassāvine viharante, appekacce na paralokavajjabhayadassāvine viharante;

pli-tv-kd1:5.12.1.eng: When he had seen this, the Buddha replied to Sahampati in verse:

pli-tv-kd1:5.12.2.eng: “The doors to the freedom from death are open!

pli-tv-kd1:5.12.3.eng: May those who hear release their faith.

pli-tv-kd1:5.12.5.eng: I did not speak the sublime and subtle Truth.”

pli-tv-kd1:5.13.2.pli: “katāvakāso khomhi bhagavatā dhammadesanāyā”ti bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā tatthevantaradhāyi.
pli-tv-kd1:5.13.2.eng: “The Buddha has consented to teach.” He bowed down, circumambulated the Buddha with his right side toward him, and disappeared right there.

pli-tv-kd1:5.13.3.eng: The account of the supreme being’s request is finished.

pli-tv-kd1:6.1.0.eng: 6. The account of the group of five

pli-tv-kd1:6.1.2.pli: “kassa nu kho ahaṃ paṭhamaṃ dhammaṃ deseyyaṃ?

pli-tv-kd1:6.1.3.eng: Who will understand this Teaching quickly?”

pli-tv-kd1:6.1.5.pli: “ayaṃ kho āḷāro kālāmo paṇḍito byatto medhāvī dīgharattaṃ apparajakkhajātiko;
pli-tv-kd1:6.1.5.eng: “Ālāra Kālāma is wise and competent, and has for a long time had little dust in his eyes.

pli-tv-kd1:6.1.6.pli: yannūnāhaṃ āḷārassa kālāmassa paṭhamaṃ dhammaṃ deseyyaṃ, so imaṃ dhammaṃ khippameva ājānissatī”ti.
pli-tv-kd1:6.1.6.eng: Let me teach him first. He will understand it quickly.”

pli-tv-kd1:6.2.1.pli: Atha kho antarahitā devatā bhagavato ārocesi—“sattāhakālaṅkato, bhante, āḷāro kālāmo”ti.
pli-tv-kd1:6.2.1.eng: But an invisible god informed the Buddha, “Sir, Ālāra Kālāma died seven days ago,”

pli-tv-kd1:6.2.2.pli: Bhagavatopi kho ñāṇaṃ udapādi—“sattāhakālaṅkato āḷāro kālāmo”ti.
pli-tv-kd1:6.2.2.eng: and the Buddha also knew this for himself.

pli-tv-kd1:6.2.5.pli: sace hi so imaṃ dhammaṃ suṇeyya, khippameva ājāneyyā”ti.
pli-tv-kd1:6.2.5.eng: If he had heard this Teaching, he would have understood it quickly.”

pli-tv-kd1:6.3.2.pli: “kassa nu kho ahaṃ paṭhamaṃ dhammaṃ deseyyaṃ?

pli-tv-kd1:6.3.3.eng: Who will understand this Teaching quickly?”

pli-tv-kd1:6.3.5.pli: “ayaṃ kho udako rāmaputto paṇḍito byatto medhāvī dīgharattaṃ apparajakkhajātiko;
pli-tv-kd1:6.3.5.eng: “Udaka Rāmaputta is wise and competent, and has for a long time had little dust in his eyes.

pli-tv-kd1:6.3.6.pli: yannūnāhaṃ udakassa rāmaputtassa paṭhamaṃ dhammaṃ deseyyaṃ, so imaṃ dhammaṃ khippameva ājānissatī”ti.
pli-tv-kd1:6.3.6.eng: Let me teach him first. He will understand it quickly.”

pli-tv-kd1:6.4.1.pli: Atha kho antarahitā devatā bhagavato ārocesi—“abhidosakālaṅkato, bhante, udako rāmaputto”ti.
pli-tv-kd1:6.4.1.eng: But an invisible god informed the Buddha, “Sir, Udaka Rāmaputta died last night,”

pli-tv-kd1:6.4.2.pli: Bhagavatopi kho ñāṇaṃ udapādi—“abhidosakālaṅkato udako rāmaputto”ti.
pli-tv-kd1:6.4.2.eng: and the Buddha also knew this for himself.

pli-tv-kd1:6.4.5.pli: sace hi so imaṃ dhammaṃ suṇeyya, khippameva ājāneyyā”ti.
pli-tv-kd1:6.4.5.eng: If he had heard this Teaching, he would have understood it quickly.”

pli-tv-kd1:6.5.2.pli: “kassa nu kho ahaṃ paṭhamaṃ dhammaṃ deseyyaṃ?

pli-tv-kd1:6.5.3.eng: Who will understand this Teaching quickly?”

pli-tv-kd1:6.5.5.pli: “bahukārā kho me pañcavaggiyā bhikkhū, ye maṃ padhānapahitattaṃ upaṭṭhahiṃsu;
pli-tv-kd1:6.5.5.eng: “The group of five monks who supported me while I was striving were of great service to me.

pli-tv-kd1:6.6.1.pli: yannūnāhaṃ pañcavaggiyānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ paṭhamaṃ dhammaṃ deseyyan”ti.

pli-tv-kd1:6.6.3.pli: “kahaṃ nu kho etarahi pañcavaggiyā bhikkhū viharantī”ti?
pli-tv-kd1:6.6.3.eng: But where are they staying now?”

pli-tv-kd1:6.6.4.pli: Addasā kho bhagavā dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena pañcavaggiye bhikkhū bārāṇasiyaṃ viharante isipatane migadāye.
pli-tv-kd1:6.6.4.eng: With his superhuman and purified clairvoyance, the Buddha saw that the group of five monks were staying near Benares, in the deer park at Isipatana.

pli-tv-kd1:6.6.5.pli: Atha kho bhagavā uruvelāyaṃ yathābhirantaṃ viharitvā yena bārāṇasī tena cārikaṃ pakkāmi.
pli-tv-kd1:6.6.5.eng: Then, after staying at Uruvelā for as long as he liked, he set out wandering toward Benares.

pli-tv-kd1:6.7.1.pli: Addasā kho upako ājīvako bhagavantaṃ antarā ca gayaṃ antarā ca bodhiṃ addhānamaggappaṭipannaṃ, disvāna bhagavantaṃ etadavoca—
pli-tv-kd1:6.7.1.eng: The Ājīvaka ascetic Upaka saw the Buddha traveling between Gayā and the place of awakening. He said to the Buddha,

pli-tv-kd1:6.7.2.pli: “vippasannāni kho te, āvuso, indriyāni, parisuddho chavivaṇṇo pariyodāto.
pli-tv-kd1:6.7.2.eng: “Sir, your senses are clear and your skin is pure and bright.

pli-tv-kd1:6.7.3.eng: In whose name have you gone forth?

pli-tv-kd1:6.7.5.eng: or whose teaching do you follow?”

pli-tv-kd1:6.8.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, bhagavā upakaṃ ājīvakaṃ gāthāhi ajjhabhāsi—
pli-tv-kd1:6.8.1.eng: The Buddha replied to Upaka in verse:

pli-tv-kd1:6.8.2.eng: “I’m the victor, the knower of all.

pli-tv-kd1:6.8.3.eng: Abandoning all, I’m not soiled by anything.

pli-tv-kd1:6.8.4.eng: Through my own insight, I’m freed by the ending of craving—

pli-tv-kd1:6.8.5.eng: So who should I refer to as a teacher?

pli-tv-kd1:6.8.8.eng: In the world with its gods,

pli-tv-kd1:6.8.14.eng: I’m going to the city of Kāsi,

pli-tv-kd1:6.8.15.eng: To set rolling the wheel of the Teaching.

pli-tv-kd1:6.8.16.eng: In this world immersed in darkness,

pli-tv-kd1:6.8.17.eng: I’ll beat the drum of freedom from death.”

pli-tv-kd1:6.9.1.pli: “Yathā kho tvaṃ, āvuso, paṭijānāsi, arahasi anantajino”ti.
pli-tv-kd1:6.9.1.eng: “According to your own claim you must be a universal Victor.”

pli-tv-kd1:6.9.3.eng: Those who have ended the corruptions.

pli-tv-kd1:6.9.4.eng: I have conquered all bad traits—

pli-tv-kd1:6.9.6.pli: Evaṃ vutte, upako ājīvako hupeyyapāvusoti vatvā sīsaṃ okampetvā ummaggaṃ gahetvā pakkāmi.
pli-tv-kd1:6.9.6.eng: Saying, “May it be so,” Upaka shook his head, chose the wrong path, and left.

pli-tv-kd1:6.10.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā anupubbena cārikaṃ caramāno yena bārāṇasī isipatanaṃ migadāyo, yena pañcavaggiyā bhikkhū tenupasaṅkami.
pli-tv-kd1:6.10.1.eng: The Buddha continued wandering toward the deer park at Isipatana near Benares. When he eventually arrived, he went to the group of five monks.

pli-tv-kd1:6.10.2.pli: Addasaṃsu kho pañcavaggiyā bhikkhū bhagavantaṃ dūratova āgacchantaṃ;

pli-tv-kd1:6.10.3.eng: the group of five made an agreement with one another:

pli-tv-kd1:6.10.4.pli: “ayaṃ, āvuso, samaṇo gotamo āgacchati, bāhulliko padhānavibbhanto āvatto bāhullāya.
pli-tv-kd1:6.10.4.eng: “Here comes the ascetic Gotama, who has given up his striving and returned to a life of indulgence.

pli-tv-kd1:6.10.5.pli: So neva abhivādetabbo, na paccuṭṭhātabbo, nāssa pattacīvaraṃ paṭiggahetabbaṃ;
pli-tv-kd1:6.10.5.eng: We shouldn’t bow down to him, stand up for him, or receive his bowl and robe,

pli-tv-kd1:6.10.6.pli: api ca kho āsanaṃ ṭhapetabbaṃ, sace so ākaṅkhissati nisīdissatī”ti.
pli-tv-kd1:6.10.6.eng: but we should prepare a seat. If he wishes, he may sit down.”

pli-tv-kd1:6.11.1.pli: Yathā yathā kho bhagavā pañcavaggiye bhikkhū upasaṅkamati tathā tathā pañcavaggiyā bhikkhū nāsakkhiṃsu sakāya katikāya saṇṭhātuṃ.
pli-tv-kd1:6.11.1.eng: But as the Buddha approached, the group of five monks was unable to keep the agreement.

pli-tv-kd1:6.11.2.pli: Asaṇṭhahantā bhagavantaṃ paccuggantvā eko bhagavato pattacīvaraṃ paṭiggahesi, eko āsanaṃ paññapesi, eko pādodakaṃ, eko pādapīṭhaṃ, eko pādakaṭhalikaṃ upanikkhipi.
pli-tv-kd1:6.11.2.eng: One went to meet him to receive his bowl and robe, another prepared a seat, another set out water for washing the feet, yet another set out a foot stool, and the last one put out a foot scraper.
pli-tv-kd1:6.11.2.comm: Sp-yoj 2.694: Pādassa ṭhapanakaṁ pīṭhaṁ pādapīṭhaṁ, “A pādapīṭha is a bench for placing the feet.” Vmv 2.112: Pādakathalikanti adhotapādaṁ yasmiṁ ghaṁsantā dhovanti, taṁ dāruphalakādi, “Pādakathalika means the wooden plank, etc., with which they wash the dirty feet by rubbing.”

pli-tv-kd1:6.11.3.eng: The Buddha sat down on the prepared seat

pli-tv-kd1:6.11.5.pli: Apissu bhagavantaṃ nāmena ca āvusovādena ca samudācaranti.
pli-tv-kd1:6.11.5.eng: But they still addressed him by name and as “friend”.

pli-tv-kd1:6.12.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, bhagavā pañcavaggiye bhikkhū etadavoca—
pli-tv-kd1:6.12.1.eng: The Buddha said to the group of five monks,

pli-tv-kd1:6.12.2.pli: “mā, bhikkhave, tathāgataṃ nāmena ca āvusovādena ca samudācaratha.
pli-tv-kd1:6.12.2.eng: “Monks, don’t address the Buddha by name or as ‘friend’.

pli-tv-kd1:6.12.3.pli: Arahaṃ, bhikkhave, tathāgato sammāsambuddho, odahatha, bhikkhave, sotaṃ, amatamadhigataṃ, ahamanusāsāmi, ahaṃ dhammaṃ desemi.
pli-tv-kd1:6.12.3.eng: Listen, I’m perfected and fully awakened. I have discovered the freedom from death. I will instruct you and teach you the Truth.

pli-tv-kd1:6.12.5.pli: yassatthāya kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajanti, tadanuttaraṃ—
pli-tv-kd1:6.12.5.eng: in this very life you will soon realize with your own insight the supreme goal of the spiritual life

pli-tv-kd1:6.12.6.pli: brahmacariyapariyosānaṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharissathā”ti.
pli-tv-kd1:6.12.6.eng: for which gentlemen rightly go forth into homelessness.”

pli-tv-kd1:6.13.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, pañcavaggiyā bhikkhū bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ—

pli-tv-kd1:6.13.2.pli: “tāyapi kho tvaṃ, āvuso gotama, iriyāya, tāya paṭipadāya, tāya dukkarakārikāya nevajjhagā uttari manussadhammā alamariyañāṇadassanavisesaṃ, kiṃ pana tvaṃ etarahi, bāhulliko padhānavibbhanto āvatto bāhullāya, adhigamissasi uttari manussadhammā alamariyañāṇadassanavisesan”ti?
pli-tv-kd1:6.13.2.eng: “Friend Gotama, by practicing extreme austerities you didn’t gain any superhuman quality, any distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of noble ones. Since you have given up your striving and returned to a life of indulgence, how could you now have achieved any of this?”

pli-tv-kd1:6.14.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, bhagavā pañcavaggiye bhikkhū etadavoca—

pli-tv-kd1:6.14.2.pli: “na, bhikkhave, tathāgato bāhulliko, na padhānavibbhanto, na āvatto bāhullāya;
pli-tv-kd1:6.14.2.eng: “I haven’t given up striving and returned to a life of indulgence,”

pli-tv-kd1:6.14.3.eng: and he repeated what he had said before.

pli-tv-kd1:6.14.4.pli: Odahatha, bhikkhave, sotaṃ, amatamadhigataṃ ahamanusāsāmi, ahaṃ dhammaṃ desemi.

pli-tv-kd1:6.14.6.pli: yassatthāya kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajanti, tadanuttaraṃ—

pli-tv-kd1:6.14.7.pli: brahmacariyapariyosānaṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharissathā”ti.

pli-tv-kd1:6.15.1.pli: Dutiyampi kho pañcavaggiyā bhikkhū bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ …pe….
pli-tv-kd1:6.15.1.eng: A second time the group of five monks repeated their question

pli-tv-kd1:6.15.2.pli: Dutiyampi kho bhagavā pañcavaggiye bhikkhū etadavoca …pe….
pli-tv-kd1:6.15.2.eng: and a second time the Buddha repeated his reply.

pli-tv-kd1:6.15.3.pli: Tatiyampi kho pañcavaggiyā bhikkhū bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ—
pli-tv-kd1:6.15.3.eng: A third time they repeated their question, and the Buddha then said, “Have you ever heard me speak like this?”

pli-tv-kd1:6.15.4.pli: “tāyapi kho tvaṃ, āvuso gotama, iriyāya, tāya paṭipadāya, tāya dukkarakārikāya nevajjhagā uttari manussadhammā alamariyañāṇadassanavisesaṃ, kiṃ pana tvaṃ etarahi, bāhulliko padhānavibbhanto āvatto bāhullāya, adhigamissasi uttari manussadhammā alamariyañāṇadassanavisesan”ti?

pli-tv-kd1:6.16.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte bhagavā pañcavaggiye bhikkhū etadavoca—

pli-tv-kd1:6.16.2.pli: “abhijānātha me no tumhe, bhikkhave, ito pubbe evarūpaṃ pabhāvitametan”ti?

pli-tv-kd1:6.16.4.pli: “Arahaṃ, bhikkhave, tathāgato sammāsambuddho, odahatha, bhikkhave, sotaṃ, amatamadhigataṃ ahamanusāsāmi, ahaṃ dhammaṃ desemi.
pli-tv-kd1:6.16.4.eng: “Then listen. I’m perfected and fully awakened. I have discovered the freedom from death. I will instruct you and teach you the Truth.

pli-tv-kd1:6.16.6.pli: yassatthāya kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajanti, tadanuttaraṃ—
pli-tv-kd1:6.16.6.eng: in this very life you will soon realize with your own insight the supreme goal of the spiritual life

pli-tv-kd1:6.16.7.pli: brahmacariyapariyosānaṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharissathā”ti.
pli-tv-kd1:6.16.7.eng: for which gentlemen rightly go forth into homelessness.”

pli-tv-kd1:6.16.8.pli: Asakkhi kho bhagavā pañcavaggiye bhikkhū saññāpetuṃ.
pli-tv-kd1:6.16.8.eng: The Buddha was able to persuade the group of five monks.

pli-tv-kd1:6.16.9.pli: Atha kho pañcavaggiyā bhikkhū bhagavantaṃ sussūsiṃsu, sotaṃ odahiṃsu, aññā cittaṃ upaṭṭhāpesuṃ.
pli-tv-kd1:6.16.9.eng: They then listened to the Buddha, paid careful attention, and applied their minds to understand.

pli-tv-kd1:6.17.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā pañcavaggiye bhikkhū āmantesi—

pli-tv-kd1:6.17.2.eng: “There are these two opposites that should not be pursued by one who has gone forth.

pli-tv-kd1:6.17.4.pli: Yo cāyaṃ kāmesu kāmasukhallikānuyogo hīno gammo pothujjaniko anariyo anatthasaṃhito, yo cāyaṃ attakilamathānuyogo dukkho anariyo anatthasaṃhito.
pli-tv-kd1:6.17.4.eng: One is the devotion to worldly pleasures, which is inferior, crude, common, ignoble, and unbeneficial. The other is the devotion to self-torment, which is painful, ignoble, and unbeneficial.

pli-tv-kd1:6.17.5.pli: Ete kho, bhikkhave, ubho ante anupagamma majjhimā paṭipadā tathāgatena abhisambuddhā cakkhukaraṇī ñāṇakaraṇī upasamāya abhiññāya sambodhāya nibbānāya saṃvattati.
pli-tv-kd1:6.17.5.eng: By avoiding these opposites, I have awakened to the middle path, which produces vision and knowledge, which leads to peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.

pli-tv-kd1:6.18.1.pli: Katamā ca sā, bhikkhave, majjhimā paṭipadā tathāgatena abhisambuddhā, cakkhukaraṇī ñāṇakaraṇī upasamāya abhiññāya sambodhāya nibbānāya saṃvattati?
pli-tv-kd1:6.18.1.eng: And what, monks, is that middle path?

pli-tv-kd1:6.18.2.eng: It’s just this noble eightfold path,

pli-tv-kd1:6.18.3.pli: sammādiṭṭhi, sammāsaṅkappo, sammāvācā, sammākammanto, sammāājīvo, sammāvāyāmo, sammāsati, sammāsamādhi.
pli-tv-kd1:6.18.3.eng: that is, right view, right aim, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right stillness.

pli-tv-kd1:6.18.4.pli: Ayaṃ kho sā, bhikkhave, majjhimā paṭipadā tathāgatena abhisambuddhā, cakkhukaraṇī ñāṇakaraṇī upasamāya abhiññāya sambodhāya nibbānāya saṃvattati.

pli-tv-kd1:6.19.1.pli: Idaṃ kho pana, bhikkhave, dukkhaṃ ariyasaccaṃ.
pli-tv-kd1:6.19.1.eng: And this is noble truth of suffering:

pli-tv-kd1:6.19.2.pli: Jātipi dukkhā, jarāpi dukkhā, byādhipi dukkho, maraṇampi dukkhaṃ, appiyehi sampayogo dukkho, piyehi vippayogo dukkho, yampicchaṃ na labhati tampi dukkhaṃ.
pli-tv-kd1:6.19.2.eng: birth is suffering, old age is suffering, sickness is suffering, death is suffering, association with what is disliked is suffering, separation from what is liked is suffering, not getting what you want is suffering.

pli-tv-kd1:6.19.3.eng: In brief, the five aspects of existence affected by grasping are suffering.

pli-tv-kd1:6.20.1.pli: Idaṃ kho pana, bhikkhave, dukkhasamudayaṃ ariyasaccaṃ—
pli-tv-kd1:6.20.1.eng: And this is noble truth of the origin of suffering:

pli-tv-kd1:6.20.2.pli: yāyaṃ taṇhā ponobbhavikā nandīrāgasahagatā tatratatrābhinandinī, seyyathidaṃ—
pli-tv-kd1:6.20.2.eng: the craving that leads to rebirth, that comes with delight and sensual desire, ever delighting in this and that,

pli-tv-kd1:6.20.3.eng: that is, craving for worldly pleasures, craving for existence, and craving for non-existence.

pli-tv-kd1:6.21.1.pli: Idaṃ kho pana, bhikkhave, dukkhanirodhaṃ ariyasaccaṃ—
pli-tv-kd1:6.21.1.eng: And this is noble truth of the end of suffering:

pli-tv-kd1:6.21.2.pli: yo tassāyeva taṇhāya asesavirāganirodho, cāgo, paṭinissaggo, mutti, anālayo.
pli-tv-kd1:6.21.2.eng: the full fading away and ending of that very craving; giving it up, relinquishing it, releasing it, letting it go.

pli-tv-kd1:6.22.1.pli: Idaṃ kho pana, bhikkhave, dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā ariyasaccaṃ—
pli-tv-kd1:6.22.1.eng: And this is noble truth of the path leading to the end of suffering:

pli-tv-kd1:6.22.3.pli: sammādiṭṭhi, sammāsaṅkappo, sammāvācā, sammākammanto, sammāājīvo, sammāvāyāmo, sammāsati, sammāsamādhi.
pli-tv-kd1:6.22.3.eng: that is, right view, right aim, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right stillness.

pli-tv-kd1:6.23.1.pli: Idaṃ dukkhaṃ ariyasaccanti me, bhikkhave, pubbe ananussutesu dhammesu cakkhuṃ udapādi, ñāṇaṃ udapādi, paññā udapādi, vijjā udapādi, āloko udapādi.
pli-tv-kd1:6.23.1.eng: I knew that this is the noble truth of suffering. Vision, knowledge, wisdom, understanding, and light arose in me regarding things I had never heard before.

pli-tv-kd1:6.23.2.pli: Taṃ kho panidaṃ dukkhaṃ ariyasaccaṃ pariññeyyanti me, bhikkhave, pubbe ananussutesu dhammesu cakkhuṃ udapādi, ñāṇaṃ udapādi, paññā udapādi, vijjā udapādi, āloko udapādi.
pli-tv-kd1:6.23.2.eng: I knew that this noble truth of suffering should be fully understood. Vision, knowledge, wisdom, understanding, and light arose in me regarding things I had never heard before.

pli-tv-kd1:6.23.3.pli: Taṃ kho panidaṃ dukkhaṃ ariyasaccaṃ pariññātanti me, bhikkhave, pubbe ananussutesu dhammesu cakkhuṃ udapādi, ñāṇaṃ udapādi, paññā udapādi, vijjā udapādi, āloko udapādi.
pli-tv-kd1:6.23.3.eng: I knew that this noble truth of suffering had been fully understood. Vision, knowledge, wisdom, understanding, and light arose in me regarding things I had never heard before.

pli-tv-kd1:6.24.1.pli: Idaṃ dukkhasamudayaṃ ariyasaccanti me, bhikkhave, pubbe ananussutesu dhammesu cakkhuṃ udapādi, ñāṇaṃ udapādi, paññā udapādi, vijjā udapādi, āloko udapādi.
pli-tv-kd1:6.24.1.eng: I knew that this is the noble truth of the origin of suffering. Vision, knowledge, wisdom, understanding, and light arose in me regarding things I had never heard before.

pli-tv-kd1:6.24.2.pli: Taṃ kho panidaṃ dukkhasamudayaṃ ariyasaccaṃ pahātabbanti me, bhikkhave, pubbe ananussutesu dhammesu cakkhuṃ udapādi, ñāṇaṃ udapādi, paññā udapādi, vijjā udapādi, āloko udapādi.
pli-tv-kd1:6.24.2.eng: I knew that this noble truth of the origin of suffering should be fully abandoned. Vision, knowledge, wisdom, understanding, and light arose in me regarding things I had never heard before.

pli-tv-kd1:6.24.3.pli: Taṃ kho panidaṃ dukkhasamudayaṃ ariyasaccaṃ pahīnanti me, bhikkhave, pubbe ananussutesu dhammesu cakkhuṃ udapādi, ñāṇaṃ udapādi, paññā udapādi, vijjā udapādi, āloko udapādi.
pli-tv-kd1:6.24.3.eng: I knew that this noble truth of the origin of suffering had been fully abandoned. Vision, knowledge, wisdom, understanding, and light arose in me regarding things I had never heard before.

pli-tv-kd1:6.25.1.pli: Idaṃ dukkhanirodhaṃ ariyasaccanti me, bhikkhave, pubbe ananussutesu dhammesu cakkhuṃ udapādi, ñāṇaṃ udapādi, paññā udapādi, vijjā udapādi, āloko udapādi.
pli-tv-kd1:6.25.1.eng: I knew that this is the noble truth of the end of suffering. Vision, knowledge, wisdom, understanding, and light arose in me regarding things I had never heard before.

pli-tv-kd1:6.25.2.pli: Taṃ kho panidaṃ dukkhanirodhaṃ ariyasaccaṃ sacchikātabbanti me, bhikkhave, pubbe ananussutesu dhammesu cakkhuṃ udapādi, ñāṇaṃ udapādi, paññā udapādi, vijjā udapādi, āloko udapādi.
pli-tv-kd1:6.25.2.eng: I knew that this noble truth of the end of suffering should be fully experienced. Vision, knowledge, wisdom, understanding, and light arose in me regarding things I had never heard before.

pli-tv-kd1:6.25.3.pli: Taṃ kho panidaṃ dukkhanirodhaṃ ariyasaccaṃ sacchikatanti me, bhikkhave, pubbe ananussutesu dhammesu cakkhuṃ udapādi, ñāṇaṃ udapādi, paññā udapādi, vijjā udapādi, āloko udapādi.
pli-tv-kd1:6.25.3.eng: I knew that this noble truth of the end of suffering had been fully experienced. Vision, knowledge, wisdom, understanding, and light arose in me regarding things I had never heard before.

pli-tv-kd1:6.26.1.pli: Idaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā ariyasaccanti me, bhikkhave, pubbe ananussutesu dhammesu cakkhuṃ udapādi, ñāṇaṃ udapādi, paññā udapādi, vijjā udapādi, āloko udapādi.
pli-tv-kd1:6.26.1.eng: I knew that this is the noble truth of the path leading to the end of suffering. Vision, knowledge, wisdom, understanding, and light arose in me regarding things I had never heard before.

pli-tv-kd1:6.26.2.pli: Taṃ kho panidaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā ariyasaccaṃ bhāvetabbanti me, bhikkhave, pubbe ananussutesu dhammesu cakkhuṃ udapādi, ñāṇaṃ udapādi, paññā udapādi, vijjā udapādi, āloko udapādi.
pli-tv-kd1:6.26.2.eng: I knew that this noble truth of the path leading to the end of suffering should be fully developed. Vision, knowledge, wisdom, understanding, and light arose in me regarding things I had never heard before.

pli-tv-kd1:6.26.3.pli: Taṃ kho panidaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā ariyasaccaṃ bhāvitanti me, bhikkhave, pubbe ananussutesu dhammesu cakkhuṃ udapādi, ñāṇaṃ udapādi, paññā udapādi, vijjā udapādi, āloko udapādi.
pli-tv-kd1:6.26.3.eng: I knew that this noble truth of the path leading to the end of suffering had been fully developed. Vision, knowledge, wisdom, understanding, and light arose in me regarding things I had never heard before.

pli-tv-kd1:6.27.1.pli: Yāvakīvañca me, bhikkhave, imesu catūsu ariyasaccesu evaṃ tiparivaṭṭaṃ dvādasākāraṃ yathābhūtaṃ ñāṇadassanaṃ na suvisuddhaṃ ahosi, neva tāvāhaṃ, bhikkhave, sadevake loke samārake sabrahmake sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāya sadevamanussāya anuttaraṃ sammāsambodhiṃ abhisambuddhoti paccaññāsiṃ.
pli-tv-kd1:6.27.1.eng: So long as I had not fully purified my knowledge and vision according to reality of these four noble truths with their three stages and twelve characteristics, I didn’t claim the supreme full awakening in this world with its gods, lords of death, and supreme beings, in this society with its monastics and brahmins, its gods and humans.

pli-tv-kd1:6.28.1.pli: Yato ca kho me, bhikkhave, imesu catūsu ariyasaccesu evaṃ tiparivaṭṭaṃ dvādasākāraṃ yathābhūtaṃ ñāṇadassanaṃ suvisuddhaṃ ahosi, athāhaṃ, bhikkhave, sadevake loke samārake sabrahmake sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāya sadevamanussāya anuttaraṃ sammāsambodhiṃ abhisambuddhoti paccaññāsiṃ.
pli-tv-kd1:6.28.1.eng: But when I had fully purified my knowledge and vision according to reality of these four noble truths with their three stages and twelve characteristics, then I did claim the supreme full awakening in this world with its gods, lords of death, and supreme beings, in this society with its monastics and brahmins, its gods and humans.

pli-tv-kd1:6.29.1.eng: And knowledge and vision arose in me:

pli-tv-kd1:6.29.2.pli: akuppā me vimutti, ayamantimā jāti, natthi dāni punabbhavo”ti.
pli-tv-kd1:6.29.2.eng: ‘My freedom is unshakable, this is my last birth, now there is no further rebirth.’”

pli-tv-kd1:6.29.3.pli: Idamavoca bhagavā attamanā pañcavaggiyā bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinandunti.
pli-tv-kd1:6.29.3.eng: This is what the Buddha said. The monks from the group of five were pleased and they rejoiced in the Buddha’s exposition.

pli-tv-kd1:6.29.4.pli: Imasmiñca pana veyyākaraṇasmiṃ bhaññamāne āyasmato koṇḍaññassa virajaṃ vītamalaṃ dhammacakkhuṃ udapādi—
pli-tv-kd1:6.29.4.eng: And while this exposition was being spoken, Venerable Koṇḍañña experienced the stainless vision of the Truth:

pli-tv-kd1:6.29.5.eng: “Anything that has a beginning has an end.”

pli-tv-kd1:6.30.1.pli: Pavattite ca pana bhagavatā dhammacakke, bhummā devā saddamanussāvesuṃ—
pli-tv-kd1:6.30.1.eng: When the Buddha had set rolling the wheel of the Teaching, the earth gods cried out,

pli-tv-kd1:6.30.2.pli: “etaṃ bhagavatā bārāṇasiyaṃ isipatane migadāye anuttaraṃ dhammacakkaṃ pavattitaṃ, appaṭivattiyaṃ samaṇena vā brāhmaṇena vā devena vā mārena vā brahmunā vā kenaci vā lokasmin”ti.
pli-tv-kd1:6.30.2.eng: “At Benares, in the deer park at Isipatana, the Buddha has set rolling the supreme wheel of the Teaching. It can’t be stopped by any monastic, brahmin, god, lord of death, supreme being, or anyone in the world.”

pli-tv-kd1:6.30.3.pli: Bhummānaṃ devānaṃ saddaṃ sutvā cātumahārājikā devā saddamanussāvesuṃ …pe…
pli-tv-kd1:6.30.3.eng: Hearing the earth gods, the gods of the four great kings cried out …

pli-tv-kd1:6.30.4.pli: cātumahārājikānaṃ devānaṃ saddaṃ sutvā tāvatiṃsā devā …pe…
pli-tv-kd1:6.30.4.eng: Hearing the gods of the four great kings, the gods of the Thirty-three cried out …

pli-tv-kd1:6.30.7.eng: the gods who delight in creation …

pli-tv-kd1:6.30.8.eng: the gods who control the creations of others …

pli-tv-kd1:6.30.9.eng: the gods of the realm of the supreme beings cried out,

pli-tv-kd1:6.30.10.pli: “etaṃ bhagavatā bārāṇasiyaṃ isipatane migadāye anuttaraṃ dhammacakkaṃ pavattitaṃ appaṭivattiyaṃ samaṇena vā brāhmaṇena vā devena vā mārena vā brahmunā vā kenaci vā lokasmin”ti.
pli-tv-kd1:6.30.10.eng: “At Benares, in the deer park at Isipatana, the Buddha has set rolling the supreme wheel of the Teaching. It can’t be stopped by any monastic, brahmin, god, lord of death, supreme being, or anyone in the world.”

pli-tv-kd1:6.31.1.pli: Itiha tena khaṇena, tena layena, tena muhuttena yāva brahmalokā saddo abbhuggacchi.
pli-tv-kd1:6.31.1.eng: In that instant the news spread as far as the world of the supreme beings.

pli-tv-kd1:6.31.2.eng: Ten thousand solar systems shook and trembled.

pli-tv-kd1:6.31.3.pli: appamāṇo ca uḷāro obhāso loke pāturahosi, atikkamma devānaṃ devānubhāvaṃ.
pli-tv-kd1:6.31.3.eng: And there appeared in the world an immeasurable and glorious radiance, surpassing the splendor of the gods.

pli-tv-kd1:6.31.4.pli: Atha kho bhagavā imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi—
pli-tv-kd1:6.31.4.eng: Then the Buddha uttered a heartfelt exclamation:

pli-tv-kd1:6.31.5.pli: “aññāsi vata bho koṇḍañño, aññāsi vata bho koṇḍañño”ti.
pli-tv-kd1:6.31.5.eng: “Koṇḍañña has understood! Indeed, Koṇḍañña has understood!”

pli-tv-kd1:6.31.6.pli: Iti hidaṃ āyasmato koṇḍaññassa “aññāsikoṇḍañño” tveva nāmaṃ ahosi.
pli-tv-kd1:6.31.6.eng: That’s how Koṇḍañña got the name “Aññāsikoṇḍañña”, “Koṇḍañña who has understood.”

pli-tv-kd1:6.32.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā aññāsikoṇḍañño diṭṭhadhammo pattadhammo viditadhammo pariyogāḷhadhammo tiṇṇavicikiccho vigatakathaṅkatho vesārajjappatto aparappaccayo satthusāsane bhagavantaṃ etadavoca—
pli-tv-kd1:6.32.1.eng: Aññāsikoṇḍañña had seen the Truth, had reached, understood, and penetrated it. He had gone beyond doubt and uncertainty, had attained to confidence, and had become independent of others in the Teacher’s instruction. He then said to the Buddha,

pli-tv-kd1:6.32.2.pli: “labheyyāhaṃ, bhante, bhagavato santike pabbajjaṃ, labheyyaṃ upasampadan”ti.
pli-tv-kd1:6.32.2.eng: “Sir, I wish to receive the going forth in your presence. I wish to receive the full ordination.”

pli-tv-kd1:6.32.4.pli: “svākkhāto dhammo, cara brahmacariyaṃ sammā dukkhassa antakiriyāyā”ti.
pli-tv-kd1:6.32.4.eng: The Teaching is well-proclaimed. Practice the spiritual life to make a complete end of suffering.”

pli-tv-kd1:6.32.5.eng: That was the full ordination of that venerable.

pli-tv-kd1:6.33.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā tadavasese bhikkhū dhammiyā kathāya ovadi anusāsi.
pli-tv-kd1:6.33.1.eng: The Buddha then instructed and taught the rest of the monks.

pli-tv-kd1:6.33.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmato ca vappassa āyasmato ca bhaddiyassa bhagavatā dhammiyā kathāya ovadiyamānānaṃ anusāsiyamānānaṃ virajaṃ vītamalaṃ dhammacakkhuṃ udapādi—
pli-tv-kd1:6.33.2.eng: While they were being instructed and taught, Venerable Vappa and Venerable Bhaddiya experienced the stainless vision of the Truth:

pli-tv-kd1:6.33.3.eng: “Anything that has a beginning has an end.”

pli-tv-kd1:6.34.1.pli: Te diṭṭhadhammā pattadhammā viditadhammā pariyogāḷhadhammā tiṇṇavicikicchā vigatakathaṅkathā vesārajjappattā aparappaccayā satthusāsane bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ—
pli-tv-kd1:6.34.1.eng: They had seen the Truth, had reached, understood, and penetrated it. They had gone beyond doubt and uncertainty, had attained to confidence, and had become independent of others in the Teacher’s instruction. They then said to the Buddha,

pli-tv-kd1:6.34.2.pli: “labheyyāma mayaṃ, bhante, bhagavato santike pabbajjaṃ, labheyyāma upasampadan”ti.
pli-tv-kd1:6.34.2.eng: “Sir, we wish to receive the going forth in your presence. We wish to receive the full ordination.”

pli-tv-kd1:6.34.4.pli: “svākkhāto dhammo, caratha brahmacariyaṃ sammā dukkhassa antakiriyāyā”ti.
pli-tv-kd1:6.34.4.eng: The Teaching is well-proclaimed. Practice the spiritual life to make a complete end of suffering.”

pli-tv-kd1:6.34.5.eng: That was the full ordination of those venerables.

pli-tv-kd1:6.35.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā tadavasese bhikkhū nīhārabhatto dhammiyā kathāya ovadi anusāsi.
pli-tv-kd1:6.35.1.eng: Living on the food brought to him, the Buddha then instructed and taught the remaining monks.

pli-tv-kd1:6.35.2.pli: Yaṃ tayo bhikkhū piṇḍāya caritvā āharanti, tena chabbaggo yāpeti.
pli-tv-kd1:6.35.2.eng: The six of them lived on the almsfood brought by three.

pli-tv-kd1:6.36.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmato ca mahānāmassa āyasmato ca assajissa bhagavatā dhammiyā kathāya ovadiyamānānaṃ anusāsiyamānānaṃ virajaṃ vītamalaṃ dhammacakkhuṃ udapādi—
pli-tv-kd1:6.36.1.eng: While they were being instructed and taught, Venerable Mahānāma and Venerable Assaji experienced the stainless vision of the Truth:

pli-tv-kd1:6.36.2.eng: “Anything that has a beginning has an end.”

pli-tv-kd1:6.37.1.pli: Te diṭṭhadhammā pattadhammā viditadhammā pariyogāḷhadhammā tiṇṇavicikicchā vigatakathaṅkathā vesārajjappattā aparappaccayā satthusāsane bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ—
pli-tv-kd1:6.37.1.eng: They had seen the Truth, had reached, understood, and penetrated it; they had gone beyond doubt and uncertainty, had attained to confidence, and had become independent of others in the Teacher’s instruction. They then said to the Buddha,

pli-tv-kd1:6.37.2.pli: “labheyyāma mayaṃ, bhante, bhagavato santike pabbajjaṃ, labheyyāma upasampadan”ti.
pli-tv-kd1:6.37.2.eng: “Sir, we wish to receive the going forth in your presence. We wish to receive the full ordination.”

pli-tv-kd1:6.37.4.pli: “svākkhāto dhammo, caratha brahmacariyaṃ sammā dukkhassa antakiriyāyā”ti.
pli-tv-kd1:6.37.4.eng: The Teaching is well-proclaimed. Practice the spiritual life to make a complete end of suffering.”

pli-tv-kd1:6.37.5.eng: That was the full ordination of those venerables.

pli-tv-kd1:6.38.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā pañcavaggiye bhikkhū āmantesi—
pli-tv-kd1:6.38.1.eng: Then the Buddha addressed the group of five:

pli-tv-kd1:6.38.3.pli: Rūpañca hidaṃ, bhikkhave, attā abhavissa, nayidaṃ rūpaṃ ābādhāya saṃvatteyya, labbhetha ca rūpe—
pli-tv-kd1:6.38.3.eng: For if form were your essence, it would not lead to suffering, and you could make it

pli-tv-kd1:6.38.4.pli: ‘evaṃ me rūpaṃ hotu, evaṃ me rūpaṃ mā ahosī’ti.
pli-tv-kd1:6.38.4.eng: be like this and not be like that.

pli-tv-kd1:6.38.5.pli: Yasmā ca kho, bhikkhave, rūpaṃ anattā, tasmā rūpaṃ ābādhāya saṃvattati, na ca labbhati rūpe—
pli-tv-kd1:6.38.5.eng: But because form is not your essence, it leads to suffering, and you can’t make it

pli-tv-kd1:6.38.6.pli: ‘evaṃ me rūpaṃ hotu, evaṃ me rūpaṃ mā ahosī’ti.
pli-tv-kd1:6.38.6.eng: be like this and not be like that.

pli-tv-kd1:6.39.2.pli: Vedanā ca hidaṃ, bhikkhave, attā abhavissa, nayidaṃ vedanā ābādhāya saṃvatteyya, labbhetha ca vedanāya—
pli-tv-kd1:6.39.2.eng: For if feeling were your essence, it would not lead to suffering, and you could make it

pli-tv-kd1:6.39.3.pli: ‘evaṃ me vedanā hotu, evaṃ me vedanā mā ahosī’ti.
pli-tv-kd1:6.39.3.eng: be like this and not be like that.

pli-tv-kd1:6.39.4.pli: Yasmā ca kho, bhikkhave, vedanā anattā, tasmā vedanā ābādhāya saṃvattati, na ca labbhati vedanāya—
pli-tv-kd1:6.39.4.eng: But because feeling is not your essence, it leads to suffering, and you can’t make it

pli-tv-kd1:6.39.5.pli: ‘evaṃ me vedanā hotu, evaṃ me vedanā mā ahosī’ti.
pli-tv-kd1:6.39.5.eng: be like this and not be like that.

pli-tv-kd1:6.40.2.pli: Saññā ca hidaṃ, bhikkhave, attā abhavissa, nayidaṃ saññā ābādhāya saṃvatteyya, labbhetha ca saññāya—
pli-tv-kd1:6.40.2.eng: For if perception were your essence, it would not lead to suffering, and you could make it

pli-tv-kd1:6.40.3.pli: ‘evaṃ me saññā hotu, evaṃ me saññā mā ahosī’ti.
pli-tv-kd1:6.40.3.eng: be like this and not be like that.

pli-tv-kd1:6.40.4.pli: Yasmā ca kho, bhikkhave, saññā anattā, tasmā saññā ābādhāya saṃvattati, na ca labbhati saññāya—
pli-tv-kd1:6.40.4.eng: But because perception is not your essence, it leads to suffering, and you can’t make it

pli-tv-kd1:6.40.5.pli: ‘evaṃ me saññā hotu, evaṃ me saññā mā ahosī’ti.
pli-tv-kd1:6.40.5.eng: be like this and not be like that.

pli-tv-kd1:6.40.6.eng: Intentional activities are not your essence.

pli-tv-kd1:6.40.7.pli: Saṅkhārā ca hidaṃ, bhikkhave, attā abhavissaṃsu, nayidaṃ saṅkhārā ābādhāya saṃvatteyyuṃ, labbhetha ca saṅkhāresu—
pli-tv-kd1:6.40.7.eng: For if intentional activities were your essence, they would not lead to suffering, and you could make them

pli-tv-kd1:6.40.8.pli: ‘evaṃ me saṅkhārā hontu, evaṃ me saṅkhārā mā ahesun’ti.
pli-tv-kd1:6.40.8.eng: be like this and not be like that.

pli-tv-kd1:6.40.9.pli: Yasmā ca kho, bhikkhave, saṅkhārā anattā, tasmā saṅkhārā ābādhāya saṃvattanti, na ca labbhati saṅkhāresu—
pli-tv-kd1:6.40.9.eng: But because intentional activities are not your essence, they lead to suffering, and you can’t make them

pli-tv-kd1:6.40.10.pli: ‘evaṃ me saṅkhārā hontu, evaṃ me saṅkhārā mā ahesun’ti.
pli-tv-kd1:6.40.10.eng: be like this and not be like that.

pli-tv-kd1:6.41.2.pli: Viññāṇañca hidaṃ, bhikkhave, attā abhavissa, nayidaṃ viññāṇaṃ ābādhāya saṃvatteyya, labbhetha ca viññāṇe—
pli-tv-kd1:6.41.2.eng: For if consciousness were your essence, it would not lead to suffering, and you could make it

pli-tv-kd1:6.41.3.pli: ‘evaṃ me viññāṇaṃ hotu, evaṃ me viññāṇaṃ mā ahosī’ti.
pli-tv-kd1:6.41.3.eng: be like this and not be like that.

pli-tv-kd1:6.41.4.pli: Yasmā ca kho, bhikkhave, viññāṇaṃ anattā, tasmā viññāṇaṃ ābādhāya saṃvattati, na ca labbhati viññāṇe—
pli-tv-kd1:6.41.4.eng: But because consciousness is not your essence, it leads to suffering, and you can’t make it

pli-tv-kd1:6.41.5.pli: ‘evaṃ me viññāṇaṃ hotu, evaṃ me viññāṇaṃ mā ahosī’ti.
pli-tv-kd1:6.41.5.eng: be like this and not be like that.

pli-tv-kd1:6.42.1.pli: Taṃ kiṃ maññatha, bhikkhave, rūpaṃ niccaṃ vā aniccaṃ vā”ti?
pli-tv-kd1:6.42.1.eng: What do you think, monks: is form permanent or impermanent?”—

pli-tv-kd1:6.42.3.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?
pli-tv-kd1:6.42.3.eng: “Is what is impermanent suffering or happiness?”—

pli-tv-kd1:6.42.5.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, kallaṃ nu taṃ samanupassituṃ—
pli-tv-kd1:6.42.5.eng: “And that which is impermanent, suffering, and changeable by nature, is it proper to regard it like this:

pli-tv-kd1:6.42.6.pli: etaṃ mama, esohamasmi, eso me attā”ti?
pli-tv-kd1:6.42.6.eng: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my essence?’”—

pli-tv-kd1:6.43.1.eng: “What do you think: is feeling permanent or impermanent?”—

pli-tv-kd1:6.43.3.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?
pli-tv-kd1:6.43.3.eng: “Is what is impermanent suffering or happiness?”—

pli-tv-kd1:6.43.5.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, kallaṃ nu taṃ samanupassituṃ—
pli-tv-kd1:6.43.5.eng: “And that which is impermanent, suffering, and changeable by nature, is it proper to regard it like this:

pli-tv-kd1:6.43.6.pli: etaṃ mama, esohamasmi, eso me attā”ti?
pli-tv-kd1:6.43.6.eng: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my essence?’”—

pli-tv-kd1:6.43.8.eng: “What do you think: is perception permanent or impermanent?”—

pli-tv-kd1:6.43.10.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?
pli-tv-kd1:6.43.10.eng: “Is what is impermanent suffering or happiness?”—

pli-tv-kd1:6.43.12.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, kallaṃ nu taṃ samanupassituṃ—
pli-tv-kd1:6.43.12.eng: “And that which is impermanent, suffering, and changeable by nature, is it proper to regard it like this:

pli-tv-kd1:6.43.13.pli: etaṃ mama, esohamasmi, eso me attā”ti?
pli-tv-kd1:6.43.13.eng: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my essence?’”—

pli-tv-kd1:6.43.15.eng: “What do you think: are intentional activities permanent or impermanent?”—

pli-tv-kd1:6.43.17.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?
pli-tv-kd1:6.43.17.eng: “Is what is impermanent suffering or happiness?”—

pli-tv-kd1:6.43.19.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, kallaṃ nu taṃ samanupassituṃ—
pli-tv-kd1:6.43.19.eng: “And that which is impermanent, suffering, and changeable by nature, is it proper to regard it like this:

pli-tv-kd1:6.43.20.pli: etaṃ mama, esohamasmi, eso me attā”ti?
pli-tv-kd1:6.43.20.eng: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my essence?’”—

pli-tv-kd1:6.43.22.eng: “What do you think: is consciousness permanent or impermanent?”—

pli-tv-kd1:6.43.24.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?
pli-tv-kd1:6.43.24.eng: “Is what is impermanent suffering or happiness?”—

pli-tv-kd1:6.43.26.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, kallaṃ nu taṃ samanupassituṃ—
pli-tv-kd1:6.43.26.eng: “And that which is impermanent, suffering, and changeable by nature, is it proper to regard it like this:

pli-tv-kd1:6.43.27.pli: etaṃ mama, esohamasmi, eso me attā”ti?
pli-tv-kd1:6.43.27.eng: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my essence?’”—

pli-tv-kd1:6.44.1.pli: “Tasmātiha, bhikkhave, yaṃ kiñci rūpaṃ atītānāgatapaccuppannaṃ ajjhattaṃ vā bahiddhā vā oḷārikaṃ vā sukhumaṃ vā hīnaṃ vā paṇītaṃ vā yaṃ dūre santike vā, sabbaṃ rūpaṃ—
pli-tv-kd1:6.44.1.eng: “So, whatever form there is—whether past, present, or future, internal or external, gross or subtle, inferior or superior, far or near—it should all be seen with right wisdom according to reality:

pli-tv-kd1:6.44.2.pli: netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attāti—
pli-tv-kd1:6.44.2.eng: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my essence.’

pli-tv-kd1:6.45.1.pli: Yā kāci vedanā atītānāgatapaccuppannā ajjhattaṃ vā bahiddhā vā oḷārikā vā sukhumā vā hīnā vā paṇītā vā yā dūre santike vā, sabbā vedanā—
pli-tv-kd1:6.45.1.eng: Whatever feeling there is—whether past, present, or future, internal or external, gross or subtle, inferior or superior, far or near—it should all be seen with right wisdom according to reality:

pli-tv-kd1:6.45.2.pli: netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attāti—
pli-tv-kd1:6.45.2.eng: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my essence.’

pli-tv-kd1:6.45.4.pli: Yā kāci saññā atītānāgatapaccuppannā ajjhattaṃ vā bahiddhā vā oḷārikā vā sukhumā vā hīnā vā paṇītā vā yā dūre santike vā, sabbā saññā—
pli-tv-kd1:6.45.4.eng: Whatever perception there is—whether past, present, or future, internal or external, gross or subtle, inferior or superior, far or near—it should all be seen with right wisdom according to reality:

pli-tv-kd1:6.45.5.pli: netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attāti—
pli-tv-kd1:6.45.5.eng: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my essence.’

pli-tv-kd1:6.45.7.pli: Ye keci saṅkhārā atītānāgatapaccuppannā ajjhattaṃ vā bahiddhā vā oḷārikā vā sukhumā vā hīnā vā paṇītā vā ye dūre santike vā, sabbe saṅkhārā—
pli-tv-kd1:6.45.7.eng: Whatever intentional activities there are—whether past, present, or future, internal or external, gross or subtle, inferior or superior, far or near—they should all be seen with right wisdom according to reality:

pli-tv-kd1:6.45.8.pli: netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attāti—
pli-tv-kd1:6.45.8.eng: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my essence.’

pli-tv-kd1:6.45.10.pli: Yaṃ kiñci viññāṇaṃ atītānāgatapaccuppannaṃ ajjhattaṃ vā bahiddhā vā oḷārikaṃ vā sukhumaṃ vā hīnaṃ vā paṇītaṃ vā yaṃ dūre santike vā, sabbaṃ viññāṇaṃ—
pli-tv-kd1:6.45.10.eng: Whatever consciousness there is—whether past, present, or future, internal or external, gross or subtle, inferior or superior, far or near—it should all be seen with right wisdom according to reality:

pli-tv-kd1:6.45.11.pli: netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attāti—
pli-tv-kd1:6.45.11.eng: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my essence.’

pli-tv-kd1:6.46.1.pli: Evaṃ passaṃ, bhikkhave, sutavā ariyasāvako rūpasmimpi nibbindati, vedanāyapi nibbindati, saññāyapi nibbindati, saṅkhāresupi nibbindati, viññāṇasmimpi nibbindati;
pli-tv-kd1:6.46.1.eng: A learned noble disciple who sees this is repelled by form, repelled by feeling, repelled by perception, repelled by intentional activities, and repelled by consciousness.

pli-tv-kd1:6.46.3.eng: Because they are desireless, they are freed.

pli-tv-kd1:6.46.4.pli: vimuttasmiṃ vimuttamiti ñāṇaṃ hoti, ‘khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā’ti pajānātī”ti.
pli-tv-kd1:6.46.4.eng: When they are freed, they know they are freed. They understand that birth has come to an end, that the spiritual life has been fulfilled, that the job has been done, that there is no further state of existence.”

pli-tv-kd1:6.47.1.eng: This is what the Buddha said.

pli-tv-kd1:6.47.2.pli: Attamanā pañcavaggiyā bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinandunti.
pli-tv-kd1:6.47.2.eng: The monks from the group of five were pleased and they rejoiced in the Buddha’s exposition.

pli-tv-kd1:6.47.3.pli: Imasmiñca pana veyyākaraṇasmiṃ bhaññamāne pañcavaggiyānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ anupādāya āsavehi cittāni vimucciṃsu.
pli-tv-kd1:6.47.3.eng: And while this exposition was being spoken to the monks from the group of five, their minds were freed from the corruptions through letting go.

pli-tv-kd1:6.47.4.pli: Tena kho pana samayena cha loke arahanto honti.
pli-tv-kd1:6.47.4.eng: Then there were six perfected ones in the world.

pli-tv-kd1:6.47.5.eng: The account of the group of five is finished.

pli-tv-kd1:6.47.6.eng: The first section for recitation is finished.

pli-tv-kd1:7.1.0.eng: 7. The account of the going forth

pli-tv-kd1:7.1.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bārāṇasiyaṃ yaso nāma kulaputto seṭṭhiputto sukhumālo hoti.
pli-tv-kd1:7.1.1.eng: At that time in Benares there was a gentleman called Yasa, the son of a wealthy merchant, who had been brought up in great comfort.

pli-tv-kd1:7.1.3.pli: eko hemantiko, eko gimhiko, eko vassiko.
pli-tv-kd1:7.1.3.eng: one for the winter, one for the summer, and one for the rainy season.

pli-tv-kd1:7.1.4.pli: So vassike pāsāde cattāro māse nippurisehi tūriyehi paricārayamāno na heṭṭhāpāsādaṃ orohati.
pli-tv-kd1:7.1.4.eng: While Yasa was spending the four months of the rainy season in the rainy-season house, he was attended on by female musicians, and he did not come down from that house.

pli-tv-kd1:7.2.1.pli: Atha kho yasassa kulaputtassa pañcahi kāmaguṇehi samappitassa samaṅgībhūtassa paricārayamānassa paṭikacceva niddā okkami, parijanassapi niddā okkami, sabbarattiyo ca telapadīpo jhāyati.
pli-tv-kd1:7.2.1.eng: On one occasion, while he was enjoying himself with worldly pleasures, he fell asleep before his attendants. He then woke up first, while the oil lamp was still burning.

pli-tv-kd1:7.2.2.pli: Atha kho yaso kulaputto paṭikacceva pabujjhitvā addasa sakaṃ parijanaṃ supantaṃ—

pli-tv-kd1:7.2.3.pli: aññissā kacche vīṇaṃ, aññissā kaṇṭhe mudiṅgaṃ, aññissā kacche āḷambaraṃ, aññaṃ vikesikaṃ, aññaṃ vikkheḷikaṃ, aññā vippalapantiyo, hatthappattaṃ susānaṃ maññe.
pli-tv-kd1:7.2.3.eng: one with a lute in her armpit, another with a tabor on her neck, still another with a drum in her armpit; one with hair disheveled, another drooling, still another talking in her sleep. It was like a charnel ground before his very eyes.

pli-tv-kd1:7.2.4.pli: Disvānassa ādīnavo pāturahosi, nibbidāya cittaṃ saṇṭhāsi.
pli-tv-kd1:7.2.4.eng: When he saw this, the downside became clear, and a feeling of repulsion stayed with him.

pli-tv-kd1:7.2.5.pli: Atha kho yaso kulaputto udānaṃ udānesi—

pli-tv-kd1:7.3.1.pli: Atha kho yaso kulaputto suvaṇṇapādukāyo ārohitvā yena nivesanadvāraṃ tenupasaṅkami.
pli-tv-kd1:7.3.1.eng: He then put on his golden shoes and went to the entrance door.

pli-tv-kd1:7.3.3.pli: “mā yasassa kulaputtassa koci antarāyamakāsi agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajjāyā”ti.
pli-tv-kd1:7.3.3.eng: “No-one should create any obstacle for Yasa going forth into homelessness.”

pli-tv-kd1:7.3.4.pli: Atha kho yaso kulaputto yena nagaradvāraṃ tenupasaṅkami.
pli-tv-kd1:7.3.4.eng: He went to the town gate,

pli-tv-kd1:7.3.5.eng: and again it was opened by spirits.

pli-tv-kd1:7.3.6.pli: “mā yasassa kulaputtassa koci antarāyamakāsi agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajjāyā”ti.

pli-tv-kd1:7.3.7.pli: Atha kho yaso kulaputto yena isipatanaṃ migadāyo tenupasaṅkami.
pli-tv-kd1:7.3.7.eng: He then went to the deer park at Isipatana.

pli-tv-kd1:7.4.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhagavā rattiyā paccūsasamayaṃ paccuṭṭhāya ajjhokāse caṅkamati.
pli-tv-kd1:7.4.1.eng: Just then, after getting up early in the morning, the Buddha was doing walking meditation outside.

pli-tv-kd1:7.4.2.pli: Addasā kho bhagavā yasaṃ kulaputtaṃ dūratova āgacchantaṃ, disvāna caṅkamā orohitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi.
pli-tv-kd1:7.4.2.eng: When the Buddha saw Yasa coming, he stepped down from his walking path and sat down on the prepared seat.

pli-tv-kd1:7.4.3.pli: Atha kho yaso kulaputto bhagavato avidūre udānaṃ udānesi—
pli-tv-kd1:7.4.3.eng: As he was getting close to the Buddha, Yasa uttered the same heartfelt exclamation:

pli-tv-kd1:7.4.5.pli: Atha kho bhagavā yasaṃ kulaputtaṃ etadavoca—

pli-tv-kd1:7.4.6.eng: “This isn’t oppressive, Yasa, this isn’t afflictive.

pli-tv-kd1:7.4.7.pli: Ehi, yasa, nisīda, dhammaṃ te desessāmī”ti.
pli-tv-kd1:7.4.7.eng: Come and sit down. I’ll give you a teaching.”

pli-tv-kd1:7.5.2.pli: “idaṃ kira anupaddutaṃ, idaṃ anupassaṭṭhan”ti haṭṭho udaggo suvaṇṇapādukāhi orohitvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami, upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
pli-tv-kd1:7.5.2.eng: “Apparently this isn’t oppressive, apparently it’s not afflictive!” excited and joyful, Yasa removed his shoes, approached the Buddha, bowed, and sat down.

pli-tv-kd1:7.5.3.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinnassa kho yasassa kulaputtassa bhagavā anupubbiṃ kathaṃ kathesi, seyyathidaṃ—
pli-tv-kd1:7.5.3.eng: The Buddha then gave Yasa a progressive talk—

pli-tv-kd1:7.5.4.pli: dānakathaṃ sīlakathaṃ saggakathaṃ, kāmānaṃ ādīnavaṃ okāraṃ saṅkilesaṃ, nekkhamme ānisaṃsaṃ pakāsesi.
pli-tv-kd1:7.5.4.eng: on generosity, morality, and heaven; on the downside, degradation, and defilement of worldly pleasures; and he revealed the benefits of renunciation.

pli-tv-kd1:7.6.1.pli: Yadā bhagavā aññāsi yasaṃ kulaputtaṃ kallacittaṃ, muducittaṃ, vinīvaraṇacittaṃ, udaggacittaṃ, pasannacittaṃ, atha yā buddhānaṃ sāmukkaṃsikā dhammadesanā taṃ pakāsesi—
pli-tv-kd1:7.6.1.eng: When the Buddha knew that Yasa’s mind was ready, supple, without hindrances, joyful, and confident, he revealed the teaching unique to the Buddhas:

pli-tv-kd1:7.6.2.eng: suffering, its origin, its end, and the path.

pli-tv-kd1:7.6.3.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma suddhaṃ vatthaṃ apagatakāḷakaṃ sammadeva rajanaṃ paṭiggaṇheyya;
pli-tv-kd1:7.6.3.eng: Just as a clean and stainless cloth absorbs dye properly,

pli-tv-kd1:7.6.4.pli: evameva yasassa kulaputtassa tasmiṃyeva āsane virajaṃ vītamalaṃ dhammacakkhuṃ udapādi—
pli-tv-kd1:7.6.4.eng: so too, while he was sitting right there, Yasa experienced the stainless vision of the Truth:

pli-tv-kd1:7.6.5.eng: “Anything that has a beginning has an end.”

pli-tv-kd1:7.7.1.pli: Atha kho yasassa kulaputtassa mātā pāsādaṃ abhiruhitvā yasaṃ kulaputtaṃ apassantī yena seṭṭhi gahapati tenupasaṅkami, upasaṅkamitvā seṭṭhiṃ gahapatiṃ etadavoca—
pli-tv-kd1:7.7.1.eng: Soon afterwards Yasa’s mother went up to his stilt house. Not seeing him, she went to her husband and said,

pli-tv-kd1:7.7.3.pli: Atha kho seṭṭhi gahapati catuddisā assadūte uyyojetvā sāmaṃyeva yena isipatanaṃ migadāyo tenupasaṅkami.
pli-tv-kd1:7.7.3.eng: The merchant then dispatched horsemen to the four directions, while he himself went to the deer park at Isipatana.

pli-tv-kd1:7.7.4.pli: Addasā kho seṭṭhi gahapati suvaṇṇapādukānaṃ nikkhepaṃ, disvāna taṃyeva anugamāsi.
pli-tv-kd1:7.7.4.eng: He saw the imprints of the golden shoes on the ground and he followed along.

pli-tv-kd1:7.8.1.pli: Addasā kho bhagavā seṭṭhiṃ gahapatiṃ dūratova āgacchantaṃ, disvāna bhagavato etadahosi—
pli-tv-kd1:7.8.1.eng: When the Buddha saw the wealthy merchant coming, he thought,

pli-tv-kd1:7.8.2.pli: “yannūnāhaṃ tathārūpaṃ iddhābhisaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkhareyyaṃ yathā seṭṭhi gahapati idha nisinno idha nisinnaṃ yasaṃ kulaputtaṃ na passeyyā”ti.
pli-tv-kd1:7.8.2.eng: “Why don’t I use my supernormal powers so that the merchant, when he sits down, doesn’t see Yasa seated next to him?”

pli-tv-kd1:7.8.3.pli: Atha kho bhagavā tathārūpaṃ iddhābhisaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharesi.

pli-tv-kd1:7.9.1.pli: Atha kho seṭṭhi gahapati yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami, upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ etadavoca—
pli-tv-kd1:7.9.1.eng: The merchant approached the Buddha and said,

pli-tv-kd1:7.9.2.eng: “Sir, have you seen Yasa by any chance?”

pli-tv-kd1:7.9.3.pli: “Tena hi, gahapati, nisīda, appeva nāma idha nisinno idha nisinnaṃ yasaṃ kulaputtaṃ passeyyāsī”ti.
pli-tv-kd1:7.9.3.eng: “Please sit down, householder. Perhaps you’ll get to see Yasa.”

pli-tv-kd1:7.9.5.pli: “idheva kirāhaṃ nisinno idha nisinnaṃ yasaṃ kulaputtaṃ passissāmī”ti haṭṭho udaggo bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
pli-tv-kd1:7.9.5.eng: he was elated and joyful. And he bowed and sat down.

pli-tv-kd1:7.10.1.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinnassa kho seṭṭhissa gahapatissa bhagavā anupubbiṃ kathaṃ kathesi, seyyathidaṃ—
pli-tv-kd1:7.10.1.eng: The Buddha then gave him a progressive talk—

pli-tv-kd1:7.10.2.pli: dānakathaṃ sīlakathaṃ saggakathaṃ, kāmānaṃ ādīnavaṃ okāraṃ saṅkilesaṃ, nekkhamme ānisaṃsaṃ pakāsesi.
pli-tv-kd1:7.10.2.eng: on generosity, morality, and heaven; on the downside, degradation, and defilement of worldly pleasures; and he revealed the benefits of renunciation.

pli-tv-kd1:7.10.3.pli: Yadā bhagavā aññāsi seṭṭhiṃ gahapatiṃ kallacittaṃ, muducittaṃ, vinīvaraṇacittaṃ, udaggacittaṃ, pasannacittaṃ, atha yā buddhānaṃ sāmukkaṃsikā dhammadesanā, taṃ pakāsesi—
pli-tv-kd1:7.10.3.eng: When the Buddha knew that his mind was ready, supple, without hindrances, joyful, and confident, he revealed the teaching unique to the Buddhas:

pli-tv-kd1:7.10.4.eng: suffering, its origin, its end, and the path.

pli-tv-kd1:7.10.5.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma suddhaṃ vatthaṃ apagatakāḷakaṃ sammadeva rajanaṃ paṭiggaṇheyya;
pli-tv-kd1:7.10.5.eng: And just as a clean and stainless cloth absorbs dye properly,

pli-tv-kd1:7.10.6.pli: evameva seṭṭhissa gahapatissa tasmiṃyeva āsane virajaṃ vītamalaṃ dhammacakkhuṃ udapādi—
pli-tv-kd1:7.10.6.eng: so too, while he was sitting right there, the merchant experienced the stainless vision of the Truth:

pli-tv-kd1:7.10.7.eng: “Anything that has a beginning has an end.”

pli-tv-kd1:7.10.8.pli: Atha kho seṭṭhi gahapati diṭṭhadhammo pattadhammo viditadhammo pariyogāḷhadhammo tiṇṇavicikiccho vigatakathaṅkatho vesārajjappatto aparappaccayo satthusāsane bhagavantaṃ etadavoca—
pli-tv-kd1:7.10.8.eng: He had seen the Truth, had reached, understood, and penetrated it. He had gone beyond doubt and uncertainty, had attained to confidence, and had become independent of others in the Teacher’s instruction. And he said to the Buddha,

pli-tv-kd1:7.10.10.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhante, nikkujjitaṃ vā ukkujjeyya, paṭicchannaṃ vā vivareyya, mūḷhassa vā maggaṃ ācikkheyya, andhakāre vā telapajjotaṃ dhāreyya—
pli-tv-kd1:7.10.10.eng: Just as one might set upright what’s overturned, or reveal what’s hidden, or show the way to one who’s lost, or bring a lamp into the darkness

pli-tv-kd1:7.10.11.eng: so that one with eyes might see what’s there—

pli-tv-kd1:7.10.12.eng: just so has the Buddha made the Teaching clear in many ways.

pli-tv-kd1:7.10.13.pli: Esāhaṃ, bhante, bhagavantaṃ saraṇaṃ gacchāmi, dhammañca, bhikkhusaṅghañca.
pli-tv-kd1:7.10.13.eng: I go for refuge to the Buddha, the Teaching, and the Sangha of monks.

pli-tv-kd1:7.10.14.pli: Upāsakaṃ maṃ bhagavā dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṃ saraṇaṃ gatan”ti.
pli-tv-kd1:7.10.14.eng: Please accept me as a lay follower who’s gone for refuge for life.”

pli-tv-kd1:7.10.15.pli: Sova loke paṭhamaṃ upāsako ahosi tevāciko.
pli-tv-kd1:7.10.15.eng: He was the first person in the world to become a lay follower by means of the triple refuge.

pli-tv-kd1:7.11.1.pli: Atha kho yasassa kulaputtassa pituno dhamme desiyamāne yathādiṭṭhaṃ yathāviditaṃ bhūmiṃ paccavekkhantassa anupādāya āsavehi cittaṃ vimucci.
pli-tv-kd1:7.11.1.eng: While his father was given this teaching, Yasa reviewed what he had already seen and understood, and his mind was freed from the corruptions through letting go.

pli-tv-kd1:7.11.3.pli: “yasassa kho kulaputtassa pituno dhamme desiyamāne yathādiṭṭhaṃ yathāviditaṃ bhūmiṃ paccavekkhantassa anupādāya āsavehi cittaṃ vimuttaṃ.

pli-tv-kd1:7.11.4.pli: Abhabbo kho yaso kulaputto hīnāyāvattitvā kāme paribhuñjituṃ, seyyathāpi pubbe agārikabhūto;
pli-tv-kd1:7.11.4.eng: the Buddha thought, “Yasa is incapable of returning to the lower life to enjoy worldly pleasures as he did while still a householder.

pli-tv-kd1:7.11.5.eng: Let me stop using my supernormal powers.”

pli-tv-kd1:7.11.6.pli: Atha kho bhagavā taṃ iddhābhisaṅkhāraṃ paṭippassambhesi.

pli-tv-kd1:7.12.1.pli: Addasā kho seṭṭhi gahapati yasaṃ kulaputtaṃ nisinnaṃ disvāna, yasaṃ kulaputtaṃ etadavoca—
pli-tv-kd1:7.12.1.eng: The merchant saw Yasa sitting there and he said to him,

pli-tv-kd1:7.12.2.pli: “mātā te, tāta yasa, paridevasokasamāpannā, dehi mātuyā jīvitan”ti.
pli-tv-kd1:7.12.2.eng: “Dear Yasa, your mother is grieving and lamenting. Please give her back her life.”

pli-tv-kd1:7.13.1.pli: Atha kho yaso kulaputto bhagavantaṃ ullokesi.

pli-tv-kd1:7.13.2.pli: Atha kho bhagavā seṭṭhiṃ gahapatiṃ etadavoca—
pli-tv-kd1:7.13.2.eng: and the Buddha said to the merchant,

pli-tv-kd1:7.13.3.pli: “taṃ kiṃ maññasi, gahapati, yassa sekkhena ñāṇena sekkhena dassanena dhammo diṭṭho vidito seyyathāpi tayā, tassa yathādiṭṭhaṃ yathāviditaṃ bhūmiṃ paccavekkhantassa anupādāya āsavehi cittaṃ vimuttaṃ.
pli-tv-kd1:7.13.3.eng: “What do you think, householder: suppose the mind of one such as you—who has seen and understood the Truth with the trainee’s knowledge and vision—while he was reviewing what he had already seen and understood, was freed from the corruptions through letting go.

pli-tv-kd1:7.13.4.pli: Bhabbo nu kho so, gahapati, hīnāyāvattitvā kāme paribhuñjituṃ seyyathāpi pubbe agārikabhūto”ti?
pli-tv-kd1:7.13.4.eng: Would he be able to return to the lower life to enjoy worldly pleasures as he did while still a householder?”

pli-tv-kd1:7.13.6.pli: “Yasassa kho, gahapati, kulaputtassa sekkhena ñāṇena sekkhena dassanena dhammo diṭṭho vidito seyyathāpi tayā, tassa yathādiṭṭhaṃ yathāviditaṃ bhūmiṃ paccavekkhantassa anupādāya āsavehi cittaṃ vimuttaṃ.
pli-tv-kd1:7.13.6.eng: “But this is what has happened to Yasa.

pli-tv-kd1:7.13.7.pli: Abhabbo kho, gahapati, yaso kulaputto hīnāyāvattitvā kāme paribhuñjituṃ seyyathāpi pubbe agārikabhūto”ti.
pli-tv-kd1:7.13.7.eng: He is now unable to return to the lower life.”

pli-tv-kd1:7.14.1.pli: “Lābhā, bhante, yasassa kulaputtassa, suladdhaṃ, bhante, yasassa kulaputtassa, yathā yasassa kulaputtassa anupādāya āsavehi cittaṃ vimuttaṃ.
